Yours sincerely,

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Mr. Philip Phelan  
Chief Training Division  
Indian Affairs Branch,  
Dept. of Mines and Resources,  
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

On checking up re 1947 accounts, I find that I lack details of the per capita grants for the following:

Wabasca - June Quarter payment of $2088.60  
Sept. " " $1858.80  
Fort George - June " " $2490.34  
Blackfoot - December " " $3370.17

Also, I find that we have not yet received the December quarter per capita grants for Whitefish and Gordon's School.

I shall be glad to have the above items cleared as soon as it is possible, in order to bring my 1947 records up to date.

This will also acknowledge your letter of Feb. 28, 1948 re the additional grant to be paid for the December Quarter 1947.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6377, file 767-3, part 1)
March 8, 1948.

Dear Miss Evans:

With reference to your letter of the 6th instant, the following is the information that you require:

**Wabasca Residential School.**
- June quarter - Average $34.81
- June Earnings..............$1,566.45
- Special Grant..............130.54
- Emergency Grant............391.61
- Total.......................$2,088.60

- September quarter - Average $30.98
- September Earnings.........$1,394.10
- Special Grant..............116.17
- Emergency Grant............348.53
- Total.......................$1,858.80

**Fort George Residential School.**
- June quarter - Average $37.59
- June Earnings..............$1,879.50
- Special Grant..............140.96
- Emergency Grant............469.88
- Total.......................$2,490.34

**Old Sun (Blackfoot) Residential School.**
- December Quarter - $94.67
- December Earnings..........$3,905.14
- Special Grant..............355.01
- Emergency Grant............710.02
- Total.......................$4,970.17
- Less Advance..............$1,600.00
- Total.......................$3,370.17

With reference to your inquiry regarding the December quarter grant for the Gordon's Residential...
School, I thought you were aware that the pupils did not return to this school after the summer holidays due to the necessity for making extensive improvements to the plumbing and heating system. The latter work is now proceeding but we do not know when it will be completed.

We have not yet received the December quarter return of the Whitefish Lake School.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education

Miss E. Evans,
Accountant,
M.S.C.C.,
604 Jarvis St.,
Toronto 5, Ont.

WINNIPEG, Jan. 14, 1904.

The Indian Commissioner,
Winnipeg.

Dear Sir,

You have no doubt heard of the total destruction by fire, in November, of the Church of England Boarding School at Wapuskow - Diocese of Athabasca.

On behalf of the Bishop, who is now in England, and by his direction, I beg now to make through you application for assistance in rebuilding this School. It will take over $2000. to rebuild and equip the School, and we shall feel very grateful to the Superintendent General for a substantial grant toward this work. The necessary preparations are now being made for building operations to go on during the summer; and I have directed the Rev. C. R. Weaver to have separate buildings this time for the school and mission-house. Before they were together and the inmates are now obliged to live- Mr. & Mrs. Weaver in a small detached room, and the Misses Hill & Parrott with the pupils of the School in the Church.

The personal losses of the staff, who lost everything, have been quite heavy. We cannot expect any help from the Department for them, but I would earnestly beg for generous treatment of the Mission.

I have the honor to be,

Dear Sir,

Yrs. respectfully,

(Sgd) W. A. Burman

Sir,

I beg to refer to the fire which destroyed the Church of England Boarding School at Lake Wapuskow in Treaty No.8, and to enclose a letter from Rev. W. A. Burman applying for help towards rebuilding. The fire took place on the 12th of November last, and the first news was received in the first days of December. It occurred at night, and everything was lost except night clothes.

It may be remembered that all buildings in connection with schools in Treaty No.8 have been put up by the two denominations who are at present attending to the educational wants of the Indians of the district, at no cost whatever to the Government, the latter providing only per capita grants for maintenance, as also school material.

I therefore submit Rev. Mr. Burman's request with strong hope that it may be granted, as it is an exceptional claim.

OTTAWA, 4th February, 1904

The Deputy Superintendent General:

The Indian Commissioner forwards a letter from Rev. Mr Burman, who asks for assistance in rebuilding the Ch. of England boarding school at Lake Wapuskaw in Treaty 8, which was totally destroyed by fire in November last. The Department never contributed anything towards the erection of this school, which was put up by the Church, and it has only been recognized as a boarding school since September 1902, when a grant of $72.00 for each of 15 pupils was allowed. Mr Inspector Conroy who visited the school last year, says that he found about 23 pupils in attendance then. The last return shows that there were 16 on the roll.

This school was conducted for some years by the Church independently of the Department and the Commissioner expresses the hope that Mr Burman's request for assistance may be granted as it is an exceptional claim. Mr Burman states that it will take over $2000.00 to rebuild and equip the school, and if the Department makes any contribution I suppose it would be expected to give at least $1000.00.

MEMORANDUM:

For the Deputy Supt. General of I.A.

The application which has been received from Rev'd. W.A. Burman for assistance to re-build the Wabiscow Boarding School buildings is the first of this nature which has been received from Treaty No. 8. It therefore behooves us to consider the matter very carefully before agreeing to any such expenditure.

If we are to adopt the same principle for the provision and maintenance of boarding schools and industrial schools in this treaty as obtains to the others, we shall add greatly to the expenditure for education. We are under no obligation to provide any special form of education under the treaty. The clause which deals with this matter is as follows:

"Her Majesty agrees to pay the salaries of such teachers who instruct the children of said Indians as to her Majesty's Government in Council may seem advisable."

The Department, in committing itself to a maintenance grant for boarding schools within the district, at once assumed a large expenditure, and it is my view that we should not add to our responsibilities further than by continuing to pay such grants, leaving the Church authorities to erect, furnish and equip the buildings. As Mr. Benson points out, we have not given any contribution towards the erection of the school, nor, as a matter of fact, any other school in Treaty 8, and I think the policy of the Department for education in this Treaty should not at present be allowed to expand.

OTTAWA, March 1904:

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 26th January last, enclosing a copy of a letter from Rev. W.A. Burman, applying for help towards rebuilding the Church of England boarding school on Lake Nipigon in Treaty 8 which was totally destroyed by fire last November, I beg to say that the Department regrets that it cannot at present make any provision for this object.

Although the Department has provided grants for boarding schools within Treaty 8, which has entailed large expenditure, it does not consider that it would at present be justified in further expanding educational work in this Treaty and it has decided not to add to its responsibilities by paying any more than the grants already provided, leaving the Church authorities to erect, furnish and equip the buildings.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Canon Gould:

Church of England in Canada,
604 Jarvis St., Toronto, Ont.
"I forgot to mention that the Home had a fire during my absence, which would have proved very disastrous but for the timely assistance of all the inhabitants of Wabasca. Apparently the chimney of the kitchen stove caught fire, that is the Tar that gathers on the Tin, (although we make a point of cleaning this particular chimney about once a month). This must have ignited the roof, from which the flames caught the Beaver Board on the Ceiling. Some of this Beaver Board dropped on a bed which caught in flames; only at this stage was it discovered. It fortunately happened in the daytime about Three in the afternoon. Mr. Lovegrove was on the spot and applied water extinguishing the bed. The Flames shooting through the roof attracted those around, and they got it under control only just in time. Fortunately there was no wind. The roof is burned about 15 feet along the ridge, and three feet down on either side, about Six slabs of Beaver Board are destroyed and Five Quilts valued at Five Dollars each. They took down the Chimney and covered the burned part again with boards and some tin Shingles. It would be a good thing if we could have enough Shingles to re-shingle the whole of the Kitchen roof. On Sunday we publicly thanked Almighty God for preserving the Mission from destruction. We need very badly another Chimney to put on the roof at the other end into which the pipes of the other stove may run. The two stoves which are constantly in use are too much for our Chimney, the soot and tar gathers too quickly."
The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I enclose an extract from a report presented by the Ven. Archdeacon A. S. White, Principal of St. John's School, Wabasca, Alta., in which he sets forth the extent of injuries recently sustained by that school through fire. It can readily be seen from the report that the consequences of the fire might have been very serious.

While it may be possible to receive some compensation in the way of insurance, it is not likely that this will be sufficient to purchase the shingles required to re-shingle the whole of the kitchen roof, or to build the chimney referred to in the Archdeacon's report. I shall be glad, therefore, to know if you will authorize our Society to undertake any expenditure which may be necessary in this connection, and any other repairs or improvements which may be required to make the school habitable during the coming winter. It is not the intention of our Society to spend any large sum of money on any of their three Indian Residential Schools in the Diocese of Athabasca, but as this school is so difficult of access, and I was unable to visit it during my visit to that part last February, I shall be glad to know the exact amount of money which you will sanction for any urgent repairs, such as those mentioned above, which may be necessary. It seems to me, so far as I am able to make an estimate at this distance, that somewhere about $1,000.00 will be required.

Believe me, Sir,

Yours very truly,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Memorandum.

Mr. Scott:

Hereunder is a request from the Rev. T.H.R. Westgate, Field Secretary, H.S.C.C., for a grant of approximately $1000 to carry out repairs to the school building in connection with the Wabasca C. of E. Boarding School.

A fire occurred at this school in March, which did damage to the roof and dormitory. Dr. Westgate states that it will be necessary to re-roof the roof of the kitchen and undertake any other work required to make the school comfortable during the next winter. He further states that it may be possible for the Church to secure some compensation from the insurance on the building, but this will not be sufficient to make the repairs and improvements needed.

We have no funds specially provided for repairs or alterations to any of the Church of England schools in the Diocese of Athabasca. In a letter hereunder to Rev. Canon Gould, dated September 27th, last, you state that, if funds are available, assistance towards the carrying out of the most urgent repairs needed at this school and the Whitefish Lake Boarding School will be granted.

I shall be pleased to receive your decision as to whether or not a grant will be allowed, as requested by Dr. Westgate.

I may add that requests have been received from the two other C. of E. Boarding Schools located in this Diocese viz: Whitefish Lake and Lesser Slave Lake, for the purchase of paint, glass, etc. These requests were made by the principals upon instructions from Dr. Westgate, who stated that the Department would be responsible, in future, for the making of repairs to the existing buildings until such time as modern buildings would be provided. Dr. Westgate has evidently written to the Standing Committee of all the Anglican Church owned buildings to this effect.

Dear Sir:

Our Society's Indian School at Wabasca in Alberta stands in need of a very great many articles of equipment, especially those for use in connexion with the farming operations, but I have asked the Principal and his staff to endeavour to carry on without these for another year, or until we have had sufficient time to formulate what we consider is the best policy to be pursued with regard to this Institution, and the other two operating in that part.

There is one article of equipment, however, which is very urgent, namely, a small gasoline or coal-oil engine and pole saw for cutting wood, and I write to ask if you can come to our assistance by furnishing these in time for use during the coming winter. The Farm Instructor at that school, who is a very practical man, recommends that the engine should be of the "Z" type, and with not less than eight horse power, such as you supplied to our Society's School at Onion Lake, and I am prepared to support his recommendation in this matter.

As the cost would not be very heavy, and the need undoubtedly very great, I shall be obliged if you will give this request favourable consideration.

Believe me, Sir,

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir,-

With further reference to my letter of Sept. 7., and your reply (No. 131-8-5) of Sept. 13, concerning the grant of $800.00 for our Society's School at Wabaseg. I beg to state that as I had no knowledge of this money being expended on the School I wrote to Archdeacon A. S. White, the Principal, for information as to whether it had been expended locally, and if so in what way and on what authority. In his reply dated Nov. 19, and which I have just received, he states that this money has not been expended. It appears to have been intended for repairs to the kitchen roof which was damaged by fire, but as it was impossible to get in the lumber before this winter they had to fix up the building as best they could with local material. As the Principal states that the permanent repairs cannot be effected before next spring, and that the whole of the $800.00 will not be required for this purpose, I shall be grateful if you will reconsider my request for the engine and pole-saw, as set forth in the above letter. If $300.00 were spent on these this year the balance of $500.00 could be carried over to next year for the repairs to the main building, and would prove, I believe, sufficient for that purpose.

I commend this request to your sympathetic consideration and have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dear Canon Gould:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, relative to repairs to church owned Indian residential schools. At an interview with church representatives in April, 1922, the Honourable the Superintendent General stated that the Department would endeavour to keep the church owned buildings in a state of good repair until such time as new buildings could be provided. Mr. Stewart's letter to you of the 21st of the same month reads in part as follows: "As an interim arrangement, the Department of Indian Affairs will endeavour to have voted the funds necessary to enable the church authorities concerned to carry out the urgent repairs on the residential school buildings owned by them."

The intention behind the words quoted seems to me to be perfectly clear, and I am pleased to carry it out. If there was any ambiguity in the wording of the letter of February 19th to Mr. Indian Agent Macdonald, your understanding is not affected thereby. You will understand that requisitioning for urgent repairs must of necessity precede the granting of funds by Parliament. There are so many pressing claims on the Appropriation for Indian Education, that many items are crowded out of the Estimates. Certain repairs, particularly minor ones, will have to be financed by the respective school management. I wish to assure you that, when funds are available, the Department will gladly assist with the necessary building activity at both state and church owned Indian residential schools.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Dear Sir:

I have received your letter of the 17th inst., #131-8-5, directing my attention to the lack of fire escapes at our Wabasca School, and to the lack of instruction in fire drill as reported to you by Mr. Indian Agent Laird. I am sending a copy of your letter to Mr. Arnold, the Acting Principal of this school, and am requesting him to furnish me with a statement in connection with these two matters. This school, like the one at Whitefish Lake, is built of logs, and is low-set. In another communication which I am forwarding by concurrent post, I have stated that the most suitable type of fire escape for buildings of this sort is peeled poplar poles placed side by side and sloping from the lower part of the upstairs dormitory window outwards to the ground. I am instructing Mr. Arnold to have fire escapes of this type installed at once, and to see that fire drill is carried out not less frequently than once a week.

In view of the specific instructions which were issued by our Commission to all Principals with regard to safeguarding the lives, and property, at the Schools from fire, I am not a little perplexed at the reports which you have received from Mr. Indian Agent Laird. I am, however, acting promptly after receiving your letters of July 17th, with regard to the situation at the Whitefish and the Wabasca Schools, and may have another communication to address to you in connection with these matters when I have received statements which I am asking the managements of these schools to furnish me.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

Last month I visited our Society's 3 Indian Residential Schools at Wabasca, White Fish Lake and Lesser Slave Lake respectively, chiefly for the purpose of ascertaining the repairs and improvements which must be provided to make it possible for the work to be continued for another year or two, until the proposed amalgamation of these 3 Schools has been completed, and a fully modern building constructed for each of the institutions visited. I went very carefully into this question with the Principal and the male agent on his staff, and enclosed herewith you will find a copy of the list which was drawn up on the spot, and a further copy of which was handed to Mr. Indian Agent Laird at Grouard. The estimated cost in each case, is only approximate, but they will serve as a guide to the total amount required. When I discussed this matter with Mr. Indian Agent Laird he expressed the wish that he had been advised of these requirements last Autumn. I explained to him that it was quite impossible for us to know at that time that precedence in the matter of new Schools to be built by your Department for our Society, was not to be given to the one we had requested on page 2 of our list of requirements for this year, namely, the one to supersede the Wabasca, White Fish Lake and Lesser Slave Lake Schools in Northern Alberta. When that list was compiled it was felt that the nominal sum of $800.00 in each case requested for repairs at these institutions (see page 4 continued of our list) would be sufficient to enable the respective School managements to carry on until the new consolidated School was ready to be occupied. The decision, however, which has been reached by mutual agreement, between your Department and our Society that precedence in the matter of Schools to be built on our behalf, should be given to Shingwauk Home, has altered the situation, and made it absolutely necessary for the
Repairs and improvements set forth on the enclosed list to be provided in order that the work at the institutions mentioned may be continued until they have been superseded by the central School which we have under contemplation.

With regard to the work involved the Principals in each case informed me that most of it could be done by local Indian labour, and they felt that it would be a very great help to the Indians who have passed through an exceedingly trying winter on account of the shortage of fur, if they were authorized to undertake the repairs and improvements at once. The situation deserves prompt and careful consideration, and I earnestly trust that you may be able to advise me in the near future that your Department will furnish an authorization for our Society to proceed with the same.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dear Sir:

During my recent visit to our Japesses School, my attention was directed to the urgent need of 4 beds for staff agents, and 6 beds for pupils, and I beg to solicit the assistance of your Department in having the same provided.

My attention was also directed to the urgent need of another staff room, and Mr. Arnold the Acting Principal informed me that he could provide this by enclosing the space in front of the main school building between the projecting ends at a cost of $150.00. As circumstances at present appear to indicate that we will be obliged to continue our work in the existing building for another year, I sincerely trust that your Department may be able to sanction this expenditure also, in addition to 25 new desks for the class-room.

As I am asking our Commission to add two more cows to the school herd, to provide two more heaters for staff rooms, 500 feet of beaver board for the walls, a garden seeder, etc., I hope it may be possible for your Department to help our Society by providing the items I have mentioned. As all freight for this school should be delivered at Slave Lake, Alberta, on the N.A.R. not later than the beginning of February, a prompt reply will oblige. If the expenditure is authorized our Commission can take care of the purchasing and shipments should your Department desire them to do so.

In another letter which will be addressed to you, you will be informed of the retirement of the Rev. S. Richardson from the Principalship of this school, and of the appointment of the Rev. A. R. Marshall to take his place. I am writing this letter
from St. Peter's School, Grouard, Alberta, but am sending it to our Winnipeg office to be typed, so that copies may be held for filing purposes.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

Referring to official letter of the 5th instant, regarding a requisition from the Principal of the Wabasca C. of E. Indian Residential School for lumber to make alterations to provide accommodation for five extra pupils, I have to inform you that a communication has been received from Rev. Dr. Westgate, Field Secretary of the Missionary Society of the Church of England, in which he informs the Department that it is the intention of the Church authorities to close the Lesser Slave Lake C. of E. Indian Residential School as from June 30th, last. He requests that the grant be increased to provide for a pupilage of thirty children at each of the Wabasca C. of E. and Whitefish Lake Indian Residential Schools.

The Department is approving of the closing of the Lesser Slave Lake School, and the increase in pupilage asked for at each of the other two schools. In view of this arrangement, consideration has been given to allowing the expenditure required in supplying the lumber asked for by the Principal of the Wabasca C. E. School in his requisition forwarded herewith, over of your letter of the 30th ultimo. You may incur an expenditure not exceeding the sum of $250 in the purchase of lumber and material to make the alterations required in fitting up extra classroom accommodation. This amount is not inside the cost of freighting. You should make the purchase and forward receipt therefor to receive consideration, and you should obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost of the building material. These accounts you should certify in the usual manner and forward to the Department for payment. You should also forward vouchers, in triplicate, with receipt attached, covering the cost of the freighting. It is to be understood that all labour is to be carried out by the school authorities without expense to this Department, and I would request that you arrange for the purchase and forwarding of the lumber, nails, etc., as mentioned in the Principal's letter, which is enclosed herewith for your information. This letter should be returned to the Department along with the account for the lumber, etc.

Dear Sir:

The Rev. K. L. Sandercock, Principal of our St. John's School at Wabasca, Alta., has directed the attention of our Commission to the very urgent need of an engine for sawing the school's supply of wood, and I am writing for the specific purpose of ascertaining if your Department can supply this item of equipment at once. The main school building itself is so old, and in need of so many repairs, some of which we are undertaking to provide, that we cannot possibly meet the cost of the engine. The old engine has rendered very good service, but the Rev. Principal reports the cylinder, carburettor, magneto, valves, etc., all so badly worn that it has no power to operate the saw. As winter is coming on he expresses his anxiety with regard to the large supply of wood fuel which will be required to meet the school's needs.

In Eaton's catalogue I find a 4-5 h.p. engine listed at a cost of $160.00 f.o.b. Winnipeg. As the weight is given at 460 lbs. the cost f.o.b. at the Wabasca School would be approximately $200.00, and I very earnestly hope your Department may be able to authorize this expenditure. If we can secure the engine for less we will assuredly do so, but in no case would we ask your Department to provide more than the $200.00 mentioned. A prompt reply will oblige.

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

PROPOSED NEW LOG-BUILDING FOR WABASCA SCHOOL, C. of B.

Rough plans attached were drawn by the Rev. K. L. Sanderson, Principal.

Following estimate was prepared by a friend of the Indian Residential School Commission, M.S.C.C., who has had much experience in erecting log-buildings such as those at Jasper on the C. N. R. and Lake Louise on the C. P. R.

"I have looked over the rough sketch of proposed mission school which conveys to me an idea of what is intended to be built, and the method of construction which is of the cheapest kind. I am not familiar with the conditions under which labour can be secured or the cost of same, but I would advise you that the dimensions given provide for a fairly pretentious building consisting of three floors, Basement, Ground Floor and First Floor - and should be so constructed as to warrant a factor of safety and give reasonable satisfaction to those responsible for the building. Assuming the cheapest form of labour and material to be used in this construction I do not believe it possible to finish this school according to these sketches at a less cost than $2700.00

If you have anything to do with this I would not advise you to be a party to be in any way responsible for heating such a building with stoves without any chimney, there is too much fire hazard, nor would I advise such a thing as having the underpart of Basement Walls being formed by shutting up the earth with boards. In fact to construct log building of the type indicated by these sketches, in a satisfactory manner commensurate with safety and convenience would cost approx. $4000, and this does not include any fixtures.

Fixtures, heating, lighting, water systems, etc., plus transportation would probably cost another $3000, and thus bring the total up to approximately $7000.

Since that date our Commission had some hope of having the pupilage increased through an addition to the main school building, but the school was visited by Colonel Mermagen, their Asst. Secretary-Treasurer last December, and he reports that as the foundation logs have decayed and must be replaced next Spring, and that as the floors are so worn, and the whole building so old and comfortless as to be incapable of repair except at an expenditure amounting to the cost of a new building, it would be better not to attempt to enlarge the present building, but to concentrate our efforts on the erection of a new building instead. As the school is heated by stoves of which so many are required, and as all the material around them is so combustible, that there is an ever-present danger from fire, the Commission instructed me to inform you that they could no longer accept responsibility for any consequences which might result from an outbreak of fire. They further instructed me to secure an estimate of the cost of erecting a new and temporary log building to take the place of the school building occupied, until such time as funds are available by your Department to provide and equip one which will be fully modern, and capable of accommodating the children now in residence, and the still larger number who are awaiting admission. This estimate appears to me to be so fair and reasonable, and the whole project so feasible, even under the prevailing stringent financial conditions which it is intended to meet, that I most sincerely hope your Department may accept it and authorize our Society to proceed with the collection of logs and other building material, so that the work of erecting the building may begin as soon as the frost is out of the ground in the Spring.

Dear Sir:-

Re:- Wabasca Main-School Building, C. of E.

The condition of the above mentioned building has been a cause of increasing concern to our Commission for some years past. An examination of their records shows that as long ago as Nov. 22nd, 1923 they included in their list of requirements to be provided by your Department a "new school at Wabasca with increased capacity of enrolment". Your Department recognized the need, even at that early date, but as the result of conferences between the Deputy Superintendent General, and the late Superintendent of Indian Education (Mr. Ferrier), and our General Secretary, it was later agreed to have one large and fully modern building erected on or near a Reserve at the west end of Lesser Slave Lake, which would amalgamate and supersede the three existing schools built and administered by our Church in that part, namely, St. Peter's at Grouard, St. Andrew's at White Fish Lake, and St. John's at Wabasca. For some reason or another, the central building was never provided, and we continued to carry on as before, until the expense for repairs and maintenance became unbearable in June 1932, when St. Peter's School was closed, and the pupils then in residence were transferred to St. Andrew's School at White Fish Lake.

July 7th. Sunday. At Wabasca.

Visited the Church of England Indian Residential School. Have found the buildings derelict and in such a state that it is impossible for the staff to keep them in good shape. Due to this, hygienic conditions are poor and there is no doubt that the several deaths that occurred there from Tuberculosis are due to such unsatisfactory conditions. The quota which has been brought up to 35 is excessive as the school lacks accommodation for that amount. I would recommend the department to investigate the possibility of either building a new school or closing this one entirely.

September 1st, 1937.

Dear Sir:

In a letter recently received from the Rev. Principal Sandercock of our St. John's School at Wabasca, Alberta, he informs me of a survey which has just been completed, by Government Surveyors, under the direction of the Indian Agent, in the Wabasca District, the object of the survey, so far as he understood the same, being part of a plan which your Department has under contemplation of moving all the Indians, on all of the four Wabasca Reserves, to one central location.

As this plan, if carried out may affect the location of the new and larger school building which we sincerely hope may soon be provided by your Department for the benefit of the Indian adherents of our Church in the Wabasca District, our Commission would like to have confirmation of the information received from Principal Sandercock, and further information as to when the proposed plan is to come into effect.

Should the centralisation scheme be carried out, it seemed to the members of our Commission at a meeting held yesterday, under the Chairmanship of His Grace, Archbishop Matheson, that our new school should be located on the new reserve, and I was instructed to file the request immediately with your Department that Section 16, which is included in the land recently surveyed, be held for this specific purpose. This letter is being written in keeping with that instruction, and it is earnestly hoped that the request it embodies, may be sympathetically considered and granted.

Your immediate servant,

[Signature]

Field Secretary, M. S. C. C.

Ottawa, September 15, 1937.

Dear Dr. Westgate:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the first instant, in which you refer to the survey undertaken and completed in the Wabasca district.

The records here indicate that a survey of the new Wabasca reserve has now been completed, but the Surveyor General, in a letter to the Department dated September 10th, indicates that the plan and detailed description of the land selected is not yet available. In view of this fact, no steps have been taken to move the Indians of the four Wabasca reserves to one central location.

I note, with interest, the recommendation of your Commission, that Section 16, which is included in the land recently surveyed, be set apart as a school site. The officials of the Department inform me that it has not been the practice in the past to set apart any particular area for this purpose until the erection of the school itself is actually under discussion. I am convinced, however, that the representatives of your Church will experience no difficulty whatever in coming to a satisfactory agreement with respect to a suitable site.

The Department at the present time is experiencing a great deal of difficulty in securing an adequate

Rev. T. B. R. Westgate, D.D.,
Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.,
39-43 The Bible House,
Alexander Ave.,
Winnipeg, Man.
adequate water supply at a number of residential schools in western Canada. The suggestion has been made that at least one residential school should be moved eight miles to a new location. I am personally convinced that the utmost possible care will have to be exercised in the selection of school sites in the future. We have certainly not at our disposal at the moment sufficient evidence to justify us in making a definite commitment with respect to the suitability or section 16 for the purpose you have in mind. Your letter will be kept on file for reference and your request given consideration when the plans and description of the land selected reach the Department.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir,

Re Repairs: File #5-87
I am delighted to know of the possibility of a $500.00 grant for repairs to these buildings and sincerely hope that the possibility may become a reality.

I am enclosing a list of materials I estimate will be required to carry out the most needed repairs. Twelve months ago we were able to do a great deal of external work which has proved most beneficial. Labour was then the chief item. I now propose to do as much as possible to the interiors, especially upstairs. What is most needed is wall board on all four walls and in some parts on ceilings. Much of this has never been done with a consequent large loss of heat. Stove pipes also need replacing, some roofing and window repairs, also flooring and many other general repairs.

I am quoting from Ashdown's for most of the material. Doors possibly from the Clark Lumber Co. Lumber I presume from some local mill along the line. Needed Lime can be purchased locally.

I am in urgent need of stove pipes and if the grant is made shall be much obliged if they can be shipped immediately. Other items can all wait for the winter freight. The freight on stove pipes will not be excessive @ 4½ per pound.

Mr. Watkins (At Slave Lake) is our forwarding agent and I think that arrangements can be made for any necessary freighting with the people attached to this school.

Thanking you again for your kind co-operation,

Yours faithfully,

(Signed) K. L. SANDERCOCK

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report, dated 6th April, 1938, from the Minister of Mines and Resources, stating:

That the estimates for the fiscal year 1938-39, Vote Number 169, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, provide an amount of $34,582.00 for new works, repairs and purchase of equipment for the following Church owned Indian Residential Schools:

(a) ONTARIO
   Spanish Roman Catholic Residential School
   Moose Fort Church of England Residential School

(b) SASKATCHEWAN
   Thunderchild Roman Catholic Residential School

(c) ALBERTA
   Brainerd Roman Catholic Residential School
   Crowfoot Roman Catholic Residential School
   Holy Angels Roman Catholic Residential School
   Joussard Roman Catholic Residential School
   St. Albert Roman Catholic Residential School
   Sturgeon Lake Roman Catholic Residential School
   Vermilion Roman Catholic Residential School
   Wabasca Roman Catholic Residential School
   Wabasca Church of England Residential School
   Whitefish Lake Church of England Residential School.

(d) NORTHEAST TERRITORIES
   Aklakvik Roman Catholic Residential School
   Aklakvik Church of England Residential School
   Fort Resolution Roman Catholic Residential School
   Providence Mission Roman Catholic Residential School.

(e) BRITISH COLUMBIA
   Ahousaht United Church Residential School
   Cariboo Roman Catholic Residential School
   Chilcotin Roman Catholic Residential School
   Kitimat United Church Residential School
   Port Simpson United Church Residential School
   St Mary's Mission Roman Catholic Residential School
   Squamish Roman Catholic Residential School
That, as these buildings are Church owned, new works, repairs and purchase of equipment constitute a grant and, therefore, the approval of Your Excellency in Council is desirable.

The Minister, therefore, recommends that approval be given for the expenditure at the above-mentioned Indian Residential Schools of the sum of $34,562.00, same to be chargeable to Vote Number 169, 1938-39, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources.

The Committee concur in the foregoing recommendation and submit the same for approval.

E. J. Lemire,

Lesser Slave Lake Agency,
Driftpile, Alta., Feb. 10th, 1939.

Sir:
I beg to submit, below, my report on a recent trip to Wabasca Reserves.

Wabasca

On Thursday A.M. January 26th, I visited the C.E. Mission. The staff consists of the following: Rev. G.N. Middleton, Principal; Miss I. Healy, R.N., Matron; Miss Turner, School teacher; Miss Atkinson, Kitchen matron and Mr. Barnes, Farm Instructor. There were 39 pupils in the school, of which 21 girls and 18 boys. They all appeared healthy and well kept. The girls are taught housework, sewing and cooking. The boys are taught general farming. The mission has the following stock; four horses, four milk cows, four calves and thirty chickens. I have no comment to make on the buildings, except that they are old, unsanitary and not very comfortable either.

N.P. L'Heureux,
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Bailey:

Following up our letter to you under date of November 19th, we wish to convey to you that we would appreciate it very much if you could let us have your cheque for this account, amounting to $205.62, so that we would get it before the end of the year.

You perhaps would not fully appreciate how important it is to us that we get all collections possible in before we close up our books for the end of the year. You no doubt would like to have your accounts paid as well, and if you could let us have this money we can pay that many more of our accounts, as our resources to pay depend upon our collections. We would appreciate very much, Mr. Bailey, anything you can do for us at this time in this regard.

Thanking you, and wishing you every happiness throughout the Yuletide Season,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Ottawa, October 3, 1941.

Dear Sir:

You are probably aware that during the last fiscal year the building program of the Government, with the exception of buildings necessary for the prosecution of the war, was completely suspended. The appropriations usually set apart for the repair of buildings at Indian day and residential schools, post offices and government buildings generally was also reduced to the lowest possible figure.

There are indications at this date that the appropriations set apart annually for the services provided by this Branch will be still further reduced in the 1942-43 estimates. If such is the case, this reduction will mean that only repairs to buildings that are urgently needed can be considered by the Department.

Requests for the construction of Indian residential schools at Wabasca and Whitefish Lake, in your agency, have been received by the Department during the last two or three years from the Anglican Church authorities and a request for the construction of a residential school at Sturgeon Lake, from Bishop Langlois, representing the Catholic Church in that district. These requests have on more than one occasion been submitted to the Minister and discussed with him. At the last conference the Minister issued instructions to have a complete educational survey of these reserves undertaken, with the object of determining whether or not local conditions on these reserves lent themselves to the construction and operation of Indian day schools. The Minister considers that it would be very inadvisable to construct additional

N. P. L'Heureux, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Driftpile,
via Kinuso, Alberta.
residential schools while the funds at our disposal now are insufficient to keep the residential schools already in operation in a proper state of repair. He believes it unwise also that we should build additional residential schools, or larger residential schools, with no assurance whatever that money will be available during the years immediately ahead of us to pay the per capita grants necessary for the operation of these schools.

It is our hope that you will be able to undertake this survey at an early date and that the survey itself, when undertaken, will be thorough and complete in every sense. You should submit figures indicating the number of children of school age on these reserves and the number of children under school age. You should submit a sketch map that will indicate the location of the Indian homes and the distance of these homes from a centre that might be selected for the establishment of a day school. You might report on the roads and the suitability of these roads, should it be decided to provide transportation for the Indian pupils from their homes to the school. Please report also on the suitability of the buildings now used as residential schools, should it be decided to purchase these and utilize them as Indian day schools. It is my understanding that the three schools referred to are all church-owned. An estimate of the cost necessary to reconstruct these buildings and equip them as day schools would be valuable to the Departmental officials.

It is just possible that, should it be decided to establish Indian day schools on these reserves, it will be necessary to provide some form of transportation and also a noonday meal. You should feel free to send forward additional information that may occur to you at the time the survey is undertaken. Information such as the general habits of the Indians and the work in which they are engaged, whether it be farming, hunting, trapping, fishing, or a combination of all of these, will be of interest to the officials and helpful to them in reaching a final decision.

Sir:

Reference your letter dated October 3, 1941, re educational survey of Sturgeon Lake, Whitefish Lake and Wabasca reserves, in connection with the possibility of operating Indian day schools.

I have not as yet visited Wabasca for this purpose, but I expect to do so in the near future and will send in my report as soon as possible. In the meantime, I am submitting informations gathered on the survey of Sturgeon Lake and Whitefish Lake reserves. I am enclosing herewith a blue print of Sturgeon Lake showing the location of the Mission and the P.C. Mission which is and would also be the most central point should it be decided to establish a day school on this reserve. Attached to the blue print is a list of the homes, in visiting order, including the number of children of school age and under in each family.

In visiting the homes I have started by the north-east, on reserve 154A. There are only two families living there, Isidore Sunshine and Francis Red Head. They are approximately five miles from the centre when one follows the trail. I then followed the east shore of the lake to Reserve 154 and then went due east to George Goodtimers (house No. 7) which is approximately five miles from the Mission. There are four families there, grouped close to one another. The majority of the Indians, however, is grouped west and south-west of the Mission, within a circuit ranging in distance from one quarter to about four miles. Six or seven families are living at the extreme west end of the reserve, near the lake, Piech Panfantasis, is a little more than four miles from the school. There is only one old Indian residing on Reserve 154B and she has no children. There is a number of large families who have no home on the reserve but only cabins on their trap-lines.

All the Sturgeon Lake Indians are trappers and hunters. There is but very little farming and cattle raising done on the reserve. A few have ventured to cultivate from half to two or three acres of grain, but they have absolutely no knowledge of it neither of how to care for horses and machinery. They do not put in gardens and very few grow potatoes. They depend solely on hunting and trapping for their living. In summer time, when they get short of food, they move into the bush, families and all, and remain there some time making provisions of meat, which they smoke and dry for future use, and then they come out and spend -
spend the summer roaming around. During the harvesting season they go out of the reserve, fifteen miles and more, seeking employment and again they take their families along as they have provisions laid aside for themself left on the reserve. There is no earning for the Indians at Sturgeon Lake and, in case of sickness and scarcity of fur and game, they are entirely dependant on the Indian Department.

Early in the fall the Indians get ready to leave for the bush, only a few old rationers remain on the reserve. They generally go away, with their families, at the beginning of October in order to prepare their lines for the trapping season which begins by the squirrel at the beginning of December. They repair their canoes, haul feed for their dogs and horses and a few provisions for themselves. They even put up hay in some of the sloughs in the bush during the summer. Some of them come out for Christmas to sell a few pelts to replenish their provisions and then they go back again and come out only in May after the rat season is over.

The same mode of living applies to the Whitefish Lake Indians as well and I imagine it would be quite a problem to operate Indian day schools on these reserves, as it would mean supporting most of the families while their children attend school.

There is one building at the R.C. Mission, at Sturgeon Lake which would be quite suitable for a day school. It is 60'x15' with a wing 26'x25' - 2½ story high. The wing is the present boys' living quarters and the other part contains three small classrooms well equipped. It is an llyr. old construction, but it appears to be in good condition. New foundations were built under it last year and Rev. Father Lajoie who is in charge of the administration of those reserves estimated it at $25,000. This building would need very little alteration for a day school.

With regard to transportation, all the trails leading to the Indian homes are fair and there is a good highway following the lakeshore.

Having no blue print of Whitefish Lake Reserve I have made a rough sketch of it and have attached a list of the Indian families as done for Sturgeon Lake. You will note that there are only eighteen houses built on Reserve 155. One family lives on Reserve 155A. It is Harvey Nahachick and he has seven children of which four are of school age. Two families, Helen Kenocono and Albert Wamsley are living on Reserve 155B at Mink Lake. This is northeast of Little Whitefish Lake, about 15 miles from Reserve #155. They both have children of school age. There are also seven families who have built their shacks outside of the Reserve, on lots. Two of these have children of school age. It is seems that the Whitefish Lake Indians do not attach any importance to where they build, they simply put up their shacks wherever it is the most convenient for them to make their living.
The present Residential School at Whitefish Lake is entirely out of place and it is not built on the reserve. It stands north of Reserve #156 and there is no Indian living there. The centre would be about half a mile southeast of the Hudson's Bay Post. There is a small flat on the east side of the creek and this is where most of the Indians are grouped. The farthest would have perhaps a little more than one mile to walk.

There are two buildings at the C.E. Mission which could be used to good advantage for a day school. One of them is the present school house, a plastered log building 18'x24' with shingle roof and spruce flooring, but it would probably need some repairs and new equipment as the present desks are very poor and insufficient for the number of pupils attending school. The second, also a log building 20'x24' -1/2 story high, shingle roof and good spruce flooring, is practically new and was built with the Department's grant as an addition to the pupils and their old living quarters. This part is unfinished, but I believe it would answer the purpose when completed. Both buildings have no foundation.

I regret to be unable to give you an estimate of the cost necessary to reconstruct and equip any of these buildings for Indian day schools. I consider that this part could be done more satisfactorily by an architect.

Your obedient servant,

N.F. L'Heureux,
Indian Agent.

Sir:

Reference your letter dated October 3rd, 1941, re educational survey of Sturgeon Lake, Whitefish Lake and Wabasca, and further to my report submitted January 22nd, 1942.

During the last week of January, I visited Wabasca Reserve, but as usual during the winter season, I found only a few families at home, the others being away on their traplines where they will remain till late in May, after the rat season is over.

I am enclosing a rough sketch of the two reserves visited, showing the location of the Indian houses, together with a list of the families including the number of children of school age and under school age.

The first reserve visited was 166C, but there was not a single Indian on it. The Indians of this reserve are all grouped at the mouth of Wabasca River, on the west shore of it. Eight families have built there, and the farthest, Pierre Neznaumoo, is approximately thirteen miles from the C.E. School across the lake. In summer time, there Indians travel by canoe but there is also a trail, following the east shore, which can be used when the Wabasca River is not too high to ford, but it is slightly further by land. At the extreme south-west corner of the Reserve is another family - Harry Alook- he is about six miles from the C.E. Mission.

On Reserve 156B I found a few families at home. There again the Indians are grouped on the lakeshore and close to the Sawridge (Slave Lake) trail. They are approximately two or three miles from the School across the lake. In summer time they cannot possibly travel any other way.

Five families have made their home outside the Reserve, about one mile from the C.E. Mission. They make their living out of odd jobs they can get from the Mission and the Hudson's Bay Post. They have poor shacks and are destitute, but it seems useless to try and persuade them to stay on their Reserve.

With regard to a suitable centre for a Day School, there does not seem to be any possible solution for this question, owing to the distance between the two Reserves.

Indian Affairs Branch,

Dear Sir:

I received your letter of June 22nd, Saturday night, so we have not wasted any time making out this order, and I hope that everything is the way you want them.

I have listed the paint for the ceilings, and the battleship grey paint for the fire escapes and window frames; they are badly in need of paint.

The moire inlaid linoleum is for the staff room floor, and the wall board is for the staff room walls.

The rocking chairs; one for the school, and one for the main building.

The nails and flooring are for the floor in the boys' play room. The floor is in very bad shape, and so are the walls, so I have listed v joint to put around the walls; wallboard is no good in the playrooms.

The chimneys are for the school roof; some of them are burnt and rusted out and are very dangerous. The heaters are also for the school. Some of the old ones are falling to pieces and they are too dangerous.

The things that are on this list are needed and needed in the worst way, and I do hope we can get them.

I never used up all the money. I thought maybe the freight would come out of the $600, and also the drugs for our school.

If all this money was to be spent on repairs, we would like the balance in 1 x 6 x 12 foot shiplap lumber. Yours truly,

(sgd) C. E. Barnes.

The Rev. H.A. Alderwood, our secretary, has informed me that he has received a letter from Mr. R.A. I beg to submit through you the following list of requirements and assure you that each item is urgently needed.

Mr. Davies then listed the articles shown on the attached form 37. He states that he is not able to find a quotation for the 12 beds shown on the form, but he states that these are also urgently needed. I am submitting the attached F. 37 covering Mr. Davies' requirements and I am sure that these articles are badly needed to effect repairs to this school.

I am sending a copy of this letter to Mr. Davies together with the F. 37 as I am aware that he could, in the ordinary way, submit his requisition on this form. However, as he is in need of these articles and the mail service to Wabasca is very slow, I am submitting this requisition in this way to save loss of time.

Acting Indian Agent.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Wabasca C.E. Indian Residential School,
Lesser Slave Lake Indian Agency,
Electoral District of Athabaska,
Province of Alberta.

I have just been advised that the main building at the above-mentioned school was destroyed by fire on the morning of Monday, January 1, 1945.

The children and staff were safely removed from the building.

The Wabasca C.E. School is a Church-owned building, erected many years ago, and reports received from time to time indicated that it was in a bad state of repair. There was accommodation for thirty-five pupils and the staff.

Acting Director.
Copy sent to Dr. Alderwood

Ottawa,
January 4, 1945.

Mr. P.J. Demers, Indian Agent, Driftpile, Alta.

I am in receipt of your telegram of the 2nd instant, advising that the main building at the Wabasca C.E. Residential School was destroyed by fire on the 1st instant. The Department was sorry to receive this information, but we were pleased to note that there was no loss of life.

Your telegram mentions only the main building and I, therefore, presume that the building used for classroom purposes, which was situated at a considerable distance from the main building, is still intact. If so, would it be possible to conduct a day school in this building? Are there sufficient children living close to the school to secure a regular attendance? Please give this matter your immediate consideration and let me have an early reply, giving me full information, especially with regard to the number of children that you consider might attend.

Acting Director.
Ottawa,
January 4, 1945.

Dear Doctor Alderwood:

I was extremely sorry to learn of the destruction of the main building at the Wabasca C.E. School. I infer that the classroom building is still intact, as I am informed that it was situated at a considerable distance from the main building. If this is correct, it might be possible to conduct a day school and, for your information, I enclose a copy of a letter which is being forwarded to the Indian Agent.

Yours very truly,

Acting Director.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re: St. Johns School, Wabasca, Alta.

I beg to confirm my telegram sent yesterday, announcing the destruction by fire of the main school building. We have no further information, and our dominant feeling is one of profound thankfulness that no lives were lost in this tragic occurrence.

I visited this school last February, and was deeply disappointed with the building. It was easily the poorest thing of its kind I had seen, and I felt that the fire hazard was considerable, and that it must have been because of great care on the part of the staff that it had escaped loss in the past. The position of this school was greatly improved when Revellon Freres went out of business and their buildings were purchased. I found that the largest building was being used as a class room with dormitory accommodation above for the older boys, and with living quarters for the teacher also. The principal's residence is a splendid building, and there is also a smaller house for the farm instructor, a laundry building and store room, and two other Revellon buildings used for storage and manual training. I have no word yet as to the disposition of the pupils, but imagine that some will be sent home and that a number will be accommodated in the remaining buildings.

It is fortunate that the Rev. A.L. Davies, our Principal, was still at the school at the time of the fire. Mr. E. Calrow, who has been appointed acting Principal, should have been arriving at about the very time the tragedy occurred.

I shall advise you further as soon as information is received and meanwhile remain, with best wishes for the New Year.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re: Wabasca School

I have to thank you for your 131-8-5 of the 4th, and for copy of letter addressed to Indian Agent Demers, at Driftpile. I note with satisfaction the suggestion that a Day School might be conducted, but am personally doubtful that there would be enough children who could attend with any regularity. I visited this school last February, and my impression is that most of the pupils come from a distance.

There is only a fortnightly mail to Wabasca, but the Principal was able to get a letter out to us on the day of the fire as follows;

"As you have already heard by wire the Main Building burned to the ground on the morning of January 1st.

At 11 a.m. Miss Bell, the Acting Matron, sent two girls down to the Mission House to report that the School building was on fire. I hurried to the school and discovered that the flames were already coming through the roof over the Junior Girls' Dormitory. It had gotten too far ahead to save the building so we rescued as much bedding, etc., as we possibly could. The fire raced through the whole building and was burnt to the ground in a few hours.

Fortunately all the children, except five, had gone home for the day and the others were awaiting the arrival of their parents. So staff and children were all safe. Miss Marcus and Miss Bell were the only staff members who were living in the building. Miss Marcus managed to retrieve all her personal belongings. Miss Bell lost about fifteen dollars ($15.00) in cash and clothing to the value of fifty dollars ($50.00). However, we are thankful that the fire occurred in the daytime and that there was no loss of life."
Mr. R.A. Hoey  
January 10 1945.

I have asked as many parents as possible to allow their children to remain at home until we hear from you and until some accommodation is arranged. It will take a little time to get forty-one children and staff housed, as we have only the Day school building, Mission House, and the cottage that was occupied by Mr. and Mrs. Spooner when you were here.

If we had lumber we might line the store warehouse and fit it up for a Dining Room and Kitchen. But lumber is scarce around here.

We also lost our Kitchen Range, and all the Bedsteads, Dressing Tables, Washstands, all tables and benches, etc. But we were fortunate to get out all we did.

P.S. We do not know how the fire started, but it was discovered between the ceiling and the roof over the Junior Girls' Dormitory.

I beg to enclose a rough plan of the buildings, which will explain the Principal's reference. It would seem that a good deal of the bedding and possibly mattresses were rescued from the burning building, and that it should be a straightforward proposition to place one or two of the Revillon buildings in a habitable state. The old store building is well constructed, and if properly lined, would make a suitable dining-room and kitchen. The former warehouse in like manner could become a girls' dormitory, and the upstairs of the former residence could accommodate all the boys. It now has the older ones only. Our Commission met yesterday, and instructed me to visit the school as soon as possible, if I should feel it advisable, and to take in a skilled builder to advise about these changes so that we may have the necessary materials freighted in without delay. As this is the time of year for freighting, there should be no difficulty in attending to this in a very short time, so that the children may be called back to the school.

Our Commission gave full consideration to the future, and will approach the Department with our suggestions after we have had the opportunity of conference with the Bishop of Athabasca.

Thanking you for your expression of sympathy, I remain,

Yours Sincerely,

H.A. Alderwood  
Secretary

I have your letter of the 10th instant, in which you state that owing to the distance the families reside from the reserve you do not think it would be feasible to operate a day school in place of the Wabasca C.E. Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re: Wabasca School

The future of this school has now been discussed by our Commission and we have also been in frequent communication with the Bishop of Athabasca. The matter will come before the Executive Committee M.S.C.C. on February 20th, and I am desired to seek the mind of the Indian Affairs Branch before that date.

I find that in October 1927 my predecessor advised the Commission that the Indian Department desired to amalgamate the three Church schools in the area, namely, Wabasca, Whitefish Lake and St. Peter's, Lesser Slave Lake. The Commission concurred in this conclusion and in 1928 urged that the Department allocate an amount to allow for the construction of a large new school. Early in 1929 it was urged that action should be taken without loss of time as "the existing buildings are no longer safe for habitation". Apparently the Bishop of Athabasca and his missionaries were strongly opposed to the suggestion and this led to action being deferred. The proposal seemed to be that the new school should be built on the site of St. Peter's, Lesser Slave Lake, near Grouard. After this school closed down on June 30th, 1932, and the few remaining pupils were transferred to Whitefish Lake, the suggestion then seemed to be that the school should be built at the last-named place.

Our correspondence shows that the proposal was again discussed in 1935 and 1936 but no agreement was reached. At the present time the Commission and Bishop Sovereign are in full agreement that it is not advisable to suggest any amalgamation, and therefore urge the construction of a new building at Wabasca. Conditions have greatly changed in our judgment in the past eighteen years and the attitude to institutional life is not what it was. Two distinct communities are found at Whitefish Lake and Wabasca, separated by 150 miles of an almost impassable wilderness, and it seems clear to us that they can best be served by two smaller schools rather than one which would be at either point. Indian sentiment appears to be more strongly than ever in favour of having children nearer home and there is much to be said for having a school as the centre of community life. In each case new buildings have been constructed or acquired since the proposal to amalgamate was dropped and our
Church has made a heavy investment along this line.

In thinking of a possible new building, our suggestion is that we should use logs which are very easily obtained in the district. We believe that we should aim at having three main school units instead of one large building. These would provide a more natural environment for the children and the school would have more of a family character. There are now 41 pupils in attendance and we suggest a building adequate for 50. The plan of having several log buildings commends itself to us in such a location as a means of reducing the danger of fire. In the present case we have lost one building but have still a number of others, and most of the food, clothing and other equipment untouched. I beg to enclose some sketches of a rough plan which we have worked out and for which an estimate of cost is being secured. This plan may be summarized as follows:

Rectangular building consisting of cement and stone basement, main floor of log and frame construction with attic above.

Basement 10' high would allow for furnace room, kitchen, dining rooms, washrooms and playrooms.

Main floor would have dormitories, offices, staff quarters and other facilities.

The attic would be used for clothing storage, sewing rooms, and similar purposes.

Local logs are abundant and their cutting and hauling would provide employment for the Indians. Rough lumber could be secured locally and other supplies obtained from Edmonton.

Fire risk would be reduced to a minimum through a central hot air furnace enclosed in cement walls, and the building of a complete chimney with glazed tiling. The solid log walls could be insulated and covered within with fireproof wall-board, and the roof covered with asbestos and other material.

This plan assumes that the present excellent classroom and teacherage and boys' dormitory shall remain in the present building, and looks forward to the eventual construction of another log building to house laundry, workshop and powerhouse. This would give satisfactory arrangements to accommodate fifty pupils and necessary staff in three buildings.

We shall be grateful if this matter can be given early consideration and that we may know what assistance we may expect from the Department in constructing such a modest building. Certainly the large school formerly contemplated would have entailed an infinitely greater cost.

Our reasons for haste in this matter arise from the peculiar difficulties of the location. The children are now housed in temporary quarters but we do not desire that they should continue in them any longer than is necessary.

I wish to refer to your letter of 2-2-45, file 131-8-5, re Wabaseg C.E. School, instructing me to visit this school and make a careful survey regarding the provision that has been made for the children, and I now wish to make the following report.

On the evening of February 13th, I left the Agency by train for Slave Lake, en route for Wabaseg, leaving Slave Lake on the morning of the 15th by team, arriving at Wabaseg on Saturday 17th.

Boys living quarters consists of a log building 26 ft. X 25 ft. 14 ft. high. The ground floor is used for inside recreation and living quarters, and the upstairs is used for the boys dormitory. There is 16 beds in this dormitory, also one cupboard 5 ft. high by 8 ft. wide, and another cupboard 4 ft. wide and 6 ft. high. The building is heated with a cast iron heater, and a 7 inch pipe. This pipe passes through the attic, and is protected with a metal chimney, making it quite safe. The only fire escape for the dormitory, is an inside stairway, which is in fair shape, but would be rather dangerous in a case of fire. There is also an addition to this building 12 ft. X 25 ft. which is used as living quarters for the boys. This is also a log building. Both these buildings are roofed with shingles.

The building occupied by the girls, is a log building 34 ft. X 34 ft. 16 ft high. The ground floor of this building is used for a kitchen, 20 ft. X 12 ft. staff's dining room 12 ft. X 12 ft. and dining room for the children 24 ft. X 34 ft. Everything is very much crowded on this floor, and it is rather difficult to have things in order.
There is a sag in the middle of this floor of approximately 10 inches. The stove in use for cooking, is an ordinary six hole range, far too small for this purpose.

The second floor of this building is used for the girls dormitory. There are 13 beds for the girls, and one bed for the guardian. There is also a stand for wash basins, and a small closet for the girls' clothing. The building is heated by a large cast iron heater with a seven inch pipe leading right to the peak of the roof. There is no attic in this building. The pipe is securely fastened, and also protected at the roof with a metal chimney. The only fire escape is an inside stairway, which is not the best, however I believe that the fire hazard is not so great in this building.

The building used for the school, is a log building 20ft. X 25ft. one storey, with 3 double windows, and heated with a cast iron stove. This building is in fair shape, but in my opinion is too small, to accommodate 41 children. This was the number of children attending at the time of this visit. I was told by the acting Principal that he did not expect any more.

All the other buildings are old log buildings, and none of them in very good shape. I do not think that any of them are worth spending any money for repairing them.

P.J. Demers
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

After discussing the problem of replacing this school and the difficulties in securing any Government action at the present time I proceeded to Toronto and laid the matter before the Executive Committee, M.S.C.C. It was not possible to expend Church funds at the present time and I was therefore instructed to make the best possible arrangements to carry on the work in the meantime. It seemed necessary to visit the school, and I accordingly arranged to charter a plane from Fort McMurray and travelled to that point after a very short stay in Winnipeg. I have already received from the Department a copy of the report made by Indian Agent Demers on February 23rd, which admirably described the situation. Some of the buildings are in good order and conditions not at all unfavorable. However, I felt keenly that another building should be secured as soon as possible, so as to relieve the over-crowding in the building now used for a Girls' dormitory above and the Dining-room and Kitchen below. Plans were made with the Acting Principal to have logs cut immediately so that a building 24' x 40' could be constructed during the summer. It was my thought that this would eventually become a smaller unit of the school and would be used for Laundry, Workshop and Storage purposes. Its use during the next school year would greatly relieve the situation and provide passable accommodation until the new school can be built.

On returning to Edmonton I made enquiries about the necessary materials to be shipped to the school to enable this building to be constructed during the summer. Pressure of time was, of course, evident by reason of the uncertain condition of the trail from Slave Lake. While in Edmonton, however, I was advised that army buildings at Dawson Lake were now available, and this seemed to offer the possibility of getting a pre-fabricated building to the school during the present month. I was able to get in touch with Mr. R. Matheson of War Assets Corporation, who gave sympathetic hearing to our case and promised his personal attention in securing and shipping a building immediately. I was able to inspect one of these huts, 20' x 40' in size, strongly and warmly constructed and in every way suitable for our purpose. I was assured that the cost of such a building would be low, and also was promised a camp cook stove which was urgently needed at the school. I am now anxiously awaiting word that these...
Mr. [illegible]

Materials have been shipped, as the West has been experiencing a period of mild weather and I am wondering about the state of the trail.

If this building can soon be erected I shall have no fear about the well-being of the children. We have an excellent staff at the present time and I found them cheerful and confident, and the children in good health and spirits.

I am enclosing a plan of the present arrangements which will amplify the report of your Agent. In view of the urgency of the need, I trust that the Government will be able to take over this building from the War Assets Corporation as our Commission will be under heavy expense in paying the cost of transportation on the railway and in freighting to the school. We have also shipped in to the school a considerable quantity of wall-board and lumber so that the present buildings may be made warm and more attractive. Our Commission are certainly prepared to do everything possible to maintain the work efficiently during this difficult period, and trust that the Department may be able to plan for the building of a new school without too much delay.

With kind regards, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

Dear Doctor Alderwood:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, with reference to the Wabasca C.E. Residential School. I have reviewed your letter very carefully and note the arrangements that you are making.

As the Wabasca C.E. School is classed as church-owned, we can only expend at that school the amount specifically provided for it in our appropriation for the fiscal year 1945-46. Our estimates were prepared last fall and have already been submitted to Parliament and, consequently, cannot be changed. I find that an amount of $700.00 is included in our 1945-46 appropriation for repairs and improvements and purchase of new equipment at the Wabasca C.E. School. In order to co-operate with you as far as we can, we are willing to expend that amount of money in whatever manner you consider in the best interests of the school. We can either apply it to the cost of the building which you state you are securing from the War Assets Corporation or we can use it for any material or equipment that might be necessary. I realize the financial strain under which your Society is working in regard to this particular school, but under present circumstances I am unable to promise more financial assistance during the coming fiscal year than the amount mentioned.

Yours sincerely,

Acting Director.

THE DEPUTY MINISTER

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I have deferred writing you about this School, hoping that I would have had a report before this from the Principal in reply to my telegraphic inquiry of some time ago but, presumably, the infrequent mail service from Wabasca is the reason for the delay.

I presume that you will soon be completing the preparation of your 1948-49 Estimates and so I would be glad if you would include in them your normal provision for miscellaneous services at this Church-owned School. I understand that you provided $500.00 in this year's Estimates for this purpose and I would like to know what you do include for 1948-49 so that we may know what we shall have to consider providing from our own resources when the Principal's report is received.

During the current year you provided $1,683.33 from your funds for an Electric Lighting Plant. It appears that this plant was switched (I hope with your knowledge) to the Fort George School because the proposed new building at Wabasca had not been erected. I am writing your branch under separate cover about this new building and if it is decided to proceed with its construction next year, perhaps you could consider providing in the 1948-49 Estimates something in the order of $2,000.00 towards the cost of an Electric Lighting Plant. The cost of a similar plant delivered to Whitefish this year was around $2,000.00, of which you provided $1,983.72.

Yours truly,

G. R. Turner
for Superintendent

Dear Colonel Neary:

Wabasca - New Log Building - Anglican Indian Residential School

With reference to my letter of 29th September, 1947, we have been hoping to have had before this information on cost of logs, sand, gravel, etc., at Wabasca to enable us to discuss with you the question of expenditure of the $10,000 provided in your 1947-48 Estimates. However, our Principal there has so far been unable to obtain any actual figures.

We have had a quotation from W. H. Clark Lumber Co., Ltd., Edmonton, on the finished lumber necessary for roof, floors, etc., on the roofing material, on windows and doors, and on cement, etc. This amounts to $9,164.33 f.o.b. Edmonton, which, I might add as a matter of interest, is $2,612.00 more than the quotation of this firm on exactly the same bill of material in February 1945.

Based on the above quotation and on adjusted 1945 estimates for other services, the approximate cost will be as follows:

(a) Building materials f.o.b. Edmonton $9,164.00
(b) Freight on (a) Edmonton to Slave Lake 600.00
(c) Hardware f.o.b. Slave Lake 500.00
(d) Paint f.o.b. Slave Lake 350.00
(e) Furnaces f.o.b. Slave Lake 2,500.00
(f) Hauling from Slave Lake to Wabasca 500.00
(g) Carpenters and other labour 3,000.00

$16,614.00

To this must be added the cost of procuring locally and delivering to the site the logs for the walls and the gravel and sand for the concrete basement floor and walls.
Allowing, say, $1,000 for this and something for incidentals and unforeseen, the cost of the completed building would probably run to $18,000, which would mean that provision of $8,000 in the 1948-49 Estimates would be necessary.

It is regretted that we cannot give any closer figures at the moment but we felt that, in view of the fact that you are now preparing your 1948-49 Estimates, you would like to have these approximate figures.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

G. R. Turner
for Superintendent
