Dear Colonel Neary:

Proposed New School
Wabasca, Alberta

As requested in your letter 131-8-5 (WT 1) of 26th November, 1947, I enclose three copies of a bill of material covering cement, lime, brick, flue tile, sawn lumber, millwork, hardware and paint required for the proposed school building at Wabasca.

Please note that a log building on stone masonry walls is contemplated and that the necessary logs, field stone, sand and gravel are not detailed on the enclosed bill of material because they can be obtained locally to best advantage.

It appears probable that the cost of the items listed on the enclosed bill of material delivered at Slave Lake Station will be around $10,000.00. If it is found that the quotations exceed that figure, the only items that can be deleted are those under the heading of paint because it would be impossible to proceed with the construction of the building next spring unless all the other items, including hardware, are delivered to Wabasca during the coming winter.

As indicated in this office letter of 20th November, the estimated cost of procuring the logs, field stone, sand and gravel in the vicinity of Wabasca is $550.00 to $650.00.

You will note from this office letter of 27th October, 1947, that the estimated cost of constructing this building, including the installation of furnaces, is in the
order of $18,000.00. Unless, therefore, you can definitely provide an additional $8,000.00 for this building in your 1948-49 Estimates to supplement the $10,000.00 already authorized, it would be inadvisable to make any commitment whatsoever because this Administration is not in a position to provide any funds for the construction of this building. I shall be glad, therefore, to be advised at an early date of your decision and whether you would like this Administration to make arrangements on your behalf for local procurement of logs, field stone, sand and gravel and for the transportation from Slave Lake Station to Wabasca of the items contained in the enclosed bill of material.

Yours truly,

Kitchen Range

Wabasca, Alberta

Reference is made to your 160-2(WT 1) of 16th January, 1948, and our conversation in your office on 22nd January.

Dear Mr. Gallagher:

This Department intends to erect a new building on the site of the present Church of England Residential School at Wabasca, Alberta during the coming summer.

The Indian School Administration of the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada has suggested to us that your services might be available as a master carpenter for this job.

Please let me know if you are willing to undertake this work and if so, advise when your services will be available and the wages you would expect.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Referring to your telephone conversation of this morning with General Turner, we have had the engineering branch of the Beach Foundry Ltd., Ottawa, go over the plans of the proposed new building at Wabasca with us.

They advise that two of the largest furnaces they manufacture, each with a heating capacity of 30,000 to 35,000 cubic feet of space, will be required. They can give immediate delivery on these furnaces but not on hot air ducts and registers. However, the ducts and registers are not unduly heavy and can be shipped in during the summer. It would be advisable, though, to ship the furnaces proper in by winter haulage as they weigh around 1000 lbs. each.

For the information of your Purchasing Branch, the specifications of the Beach Foundry furnaces required to meet the heating requirements are as follows and if purchase is made from some other firm, the specifications should be approximately the same:

Two only All-Steel Furnaces No. 727
Wood burning grates
Heating capacity - 30,000 to 35,000 cubic feet each on gravity supply.

The price f.o.b. Ottawa quoted by Beach Foundry for the above is $235.00 per furnace.

The following should be shipped with the furnaces procured:

100 feet of stove pipe (6" diameter to fit the above Beach Furnace)
6 90-degree elbows to fit above pipe
2 Tees to fit above pipe

p.t.o.
Will you please advise us of the action taken in regard to these furnaces.

Yours truly,

Henry G. Cook

Ottawa, March 17, 1948.

Mr. A. Landry, Indian Agent,
High Prairie, Alberta.

Wabasca C.E. Indian Residential School.

It is our intention to erect a classroom block at the above residential school. We have already purchased a large amount of material during the last part of this fiscal year. We will also have some funds available in our next year's appropriation for the erection of the classroom block.

Originally the M. S. C. C. had suggested the name of Mr. H. Gallagher, of the Hudson's Bay Company at Wabasca, as one who would undertake the erection of the classroom block on a day labour basis. We have now heard from Mr. Gallagher, advising that he is unable to undertake this work.

I today discussed this problem with Mr. Gooderham and he suggested to me that you might have a man in mind who could undertake the erection of this building. If you want further details as to the type of building, specifications, etc., I suggest that you contact Reverend A. B. Christie, Principal of the Wabasca School, in this regard.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.
Ottawa, March 20, 1948.

Mr. A. Landry, Superintendent,
High Prairie, Alberta.

We have the attached requisition from the Wabasca C.E. School. You will note that the principal asks for 36 desks and 12 kindergarten chairs. Are there no suitable desks in the school at the present time? The request apparently covers the seating accommodation of 48 children, while the authorized enrolment of this school is only 35.

We do not know what is meant by the term "right chair desks" and "left chair desks." The chair desks are made in three sizes, large, medium and small. Please let me know the number of each size required, taking into consideration the desks at present in the school which are still suitable for use.

When forwarding requisitions involving such heavy expenditure, you should forward a covering letter pointing out definitely if the equipment is absolutely necessary.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Re: Church of England Res. School.

I have for acknowledgement your letter of March 17th, requesting that I endeavour to locate a suitable man to act as foreman for the construction of the above noted school. All efforts were made in this vicinity to locate such a man but to date this has been to no avail. In a recent trip to Edmonton I interviewed a contractor who stated that he may be interested in the building of this school as well as the residence of the Assistant Agent at Wabasca.

The contractor, Mr. J.A. Boisvert of 8754-92A Avenue, Edmonton, Alberta; phoned me over the long distance telephone this morning and stated that he is willing to undertake the construction of the Church of England School and the residence of the Assistant Agent at Wabasca. His charge in this connection is 60% of the cost of all material F.O.B. Wabasca exclusive of excavation. He is willing however, to supervise the excavation at no additional cost. This work however will have to be done by Indian labour and horses.

Meanwhile, it would therefore be greatly appreciated if a blue print and specifications for the Church of England Residential School were Air Mailed either to Mr. Boisvert or myself. Mr. Boisvert is naturally interested to find out the exact type of construction that will be required before giving his final bid.

I have also on hand the blue print for the residence of the Assistant Agent but I have not yet received the specifications for same. It would therefore be appreciated if this
also could be received. I have personally seen various buildings built by Mr. Boisvert and I can recommend his work. He will bring his crew, which is made up of a considerable number of men, but also states that he will require Indian labour to a great extent.

The matter was discussed over with Mr. Gooderham who was here yesterday. Mr. Gooderham apparently intends to interview Mr. Boisvert and will likely report further on the matter.

A. Landry,
Superintendent.

With reference to your letter of May 2nd in which you advise me that you have located a contractor in Edmonton who will undertake the construction of the school and the residence for the Assistant Agent at Wabasca on the basis of 60% of the cost of materials f.o.b. Edmonton, I would say that we cannot figure the cost of the materials as we have not received any accounts from you. If you have not the accounts in your possession, please secure them as quickly as possible, or, in the meantime, advise us what the total cost of all materials which you ordered amounts to. We placed the order from here for the cement, heating and wiring materials but all other materials were to be ordered by you. We will need to know the exact cost of the materials in order that we can secure an Order-in-Council based on the offer of 60% of the cost of materials.

Please let me have a reply as quickly as possible by Air Mail as it would appear that Mr. Belcourt's offer is one in which we might be interested. You do not mention whether the 60% of the cost of materials is all that will be charged. Does this cover transportation of men, board and lodging of men and will the contractor supply all his own tools and equipment? We understand, of course, that we will have to pay for the excavation. Please go into the matter quite thoroughly and in the meantime we are enclosing an extra copy of the plan of this house and a list of materials.

No specification has been prepared so it is not the usual practice when Bills of Material are supplied for the architect to prepare specifications. The materials to be used are listed on the Bill of Materials and the plan shows how the house is to be constructed.
Should it be decided to accept this offer a Contract Agreement and a copy of the Minimum Wage Schedule will be forwarded for the contractor to sign. I trust that you will secure all information before writing to me again on this subject. I may say that this letter has reference only to the construction of the Assistant Agent's house but, no doubt, some of the information will also be required by the Education Branch to enable them to decide whether or not they should accept the offer.

General Executive Assistant.

Dear Sir:

Please find enclosed the approx. estimates for Asbestos roofing and the keeping of meat and fish through the summer months necessitates an ice house being built also a fire escape for the Girl's dormitory. These were mentioned to you in your recent visit to the School and you agreed as to the urgent need of the same. We have already had a number of fires from the old wooden shingles on the roof—some of which have been on for some forty years. I am enclosing a snap of the last one—the roof being only temporarily fixed for the present. I feel a constant weight of worry over the same and our vigilance has no peace or rest from one year to another and I feel that some day one of these roof fires will get too much of a start to save the School. The urgent request for these replacements is being made through you to the Indian Dept.

In reference to tin roofs, I am requesting asbestos as more durable and satisfactory in every respect. The winds from the Lake are terrific at times and metal roofs have proven to be no end of trouble in becoming loose apart from their noise and heat in summer. The Manager of the Gov. Asbestos roofing if properly put on is also 90% good for use at any future date if removed.

Re the ice house—the present one has been in use for over 50 years and as it is built of logs, you will understand that its usefulness has long since passed. It is in danger of collapsing at any time.

Re fire escape—one can be built here that will serve the purpose adequately.

Concerning the enclosed copy of the Rev. Mr. Cathcart's letter and requisition to the Acting Agent at Driftpile, Alberta, Mr. Cathcart writes me as follows:

Re: Church of England Residential School, Wabasca.

The erection of buildings at Wabasca, Lesser Slave Agency, is a real problem. It came up for discussion with the present Superintendent, Mr. Landry, when I visited that Agency last week.

I learned that Mr. J. A. Loisvert of Edmonton was prepared to make an offer to do all the Government buildings at that point this summer, and then arranged an appointment with him in Edmonton on the 23rd, where I learned that he had been in phone communication with Mr. Landry on the 22nd. I have now received a copy of Mr. Landry's letter, file 5-4-5, dated the 22nd, and I also have a report from the Labor Department office at Edmonton on Mr. Loisvert's work. This is a confidential report.

Mr. Loisvert had given me Armitage Mc Bain Lumber Company as a reference. I therefore asked the Labor official to contact a responsible member of this firm. He did so and here is his report:

"Mr. Allan Mc Bain stated that he would not recommend Mr. Loisvert either financially or as a builder. As he owed the company a large amount of money he was given two company houses to build. Evidently he paid little attention to the architect's plans and went along in his own fashion until he got into such a muddle that the company took him off the job and had someone else finish the houses." It is regretted that I got such a report, because I was favorably impressed with Mr. Loisvert.

Some other contacts must be made but nothing can be done until we have the plans and specifications and a bill of material already delivered at Wabasca. For your information, material for a staff house is also delivered at Wabasca.

If all the information with regard to these two buildings is available at this office, an honest endeavor will be made to get some contractor who will go into Wabasca and do all this work. I would therefore ask you to please send at least one set of plans, specifications, etc., here and preferably there, so that they can be sent out to any who might be interested.

G.H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

Wabasca C. E. Building Program

By now, you should have received a copy of the blue-prints dealing with the new building planned for the Wabasca Residential School. Originally the Indian School Administration of the M.S.C.C. intended to carry out this building project. However, due to the sudden deaths of the late Dr. Alderwood and Canon House, it has been necessary for the Department to assume this responsibility.

The plans and the bill of materials were prepared by the M.S.C.C. The Department has already purchased the materials listed by the M.S.C.C. as necessary and these have been forwarded to the school. Mr. Landry should have copies of these purchase orders. However, attached hereto is a copy of the original bill of materials which was sent to us by the M.S.C.C. With regard to the type of building I would like to quote from a letter of the late Canon House dated December 9:

"Please note that a log building on stone masonry walls is contemplated and that the necessary logs, field stone, sand and gravel are not detailed on the enclosed bill of material because they can be obtained to best advantage, locally.

................. ..........

"As indicated in this office letter of 20th November, the estimated cost of procuring the logs..."
field stone, sand and gravel in the vicinity of Wabasca is $550.00 to $650.00."

Insofar as we have been able to ascertain here, no provision has been made for procuring the logs required. This is unfortunate but due to the sudden deaths of the two Superintendents of the Indian School Administration of the M.S.C.C., it was impossible to clean up all the loose ends in some of their projects.

Re: Wabasca Church of England School.

I have on hand your letter of June 21st, file 131-4B-2, in which you ask that I obtain a bid from Mr. Ebraim Blouin of Jousard, Alberta, for the construction of the school block as well as the Agency residence at Wabasca.

I have today interviewed Mr. Blouin in that respect but this man is in the neighborhood of 70 years of age. Although he is reputed to possess a very high standard of carpenter skill, he himself admits that he is somewhat advanced in age to undertake such a construction, especially in a remote area such as Wabasca. I have no specifications on hand here nor bill of material, or purchase orders of any kind for the Church of England School Block. The only thing that could give him was one set of the blue prints that was forwarded here by you. It is to be noted that while Mr. Blouin himself does not appear to be interested in giving a bid, his son Alfred who is well reputed, may possibly be interested. At the present time both Alfred and Ebraim are in Whitefish Lake about to start the construction of our Day School there. They do not expect to finish that construction before the 15th of August.

As previously stated the material for the agency residence at Wabasca has reached there and is conveniently stored there. This building therefore could be started on at anytime. I regret however that I cannot say the same for the school block. Of all material that was shipped to Slave Lake in care of Mr. R.F. V., it would appear that it has all reached Wabasca except two drums. It has also been reported to me that a great deal of the material shipped had been damaged in transit. It is also understood that this school is to be built with logs on stone masonry. Only a few of the logs have been delivered on the premises and I have been informed by the Reverend Brown Christie that he was unable to get more logs supplied as the Indians refused to work for him.

While in Wabasca I made an effort to obtain from Reverend Christie as much information as I possibly could, but this was to little avail. He did not know whether he had received any purchase orders or not and also stated that as the invoices were coming in, they were sent to the M.S.C.C., after the material had been checked against it. He could not inform me whether he had received invoices or purchase orders covering all the material. The whole matter seemed to be somewhat obscure to him and from this point there is very little that I can do as I am totally unaware of what was shipped and so forth.

A. Landry,
Superintendent.

Mr. G.H. Gooderham, Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies, Calgary, Alberta.

We have your letter of the 15th instant in connection with the building at the Wabasca C.E. Residential School.

Purchase orders were issued several months ago for the materials that we were supplying and it was understood that delivery of them would be made by winter freight previous to March 31st.

Recently we had a letter from J.C. Burger Lumber Co., Edmonton, regarding purchase order 2603. They stated that they had delivered the items on this purchase order in February but have not been paid due to the fact that they did not know how to handle the matter.

We have interviewed the officials of the M.S.C.C. this morning and are advised that Reverend Mr. Davies has assumed duties as principal of the Wabasca C.E. Re: Erection of Church of England School Bldgs. - Wabasca.

It was our hope that this building could be erected by the same contractor who would erect the home for the Assistant Agent at Wabasca. It was our understanding that the material for both these buildings was already delivered to the sites, and, on this assumption, I made inquiries and got certain contractors interested in this work.

When Mr. Landry returned from Treaty payments in June, he answered a letter I had written. Attached hereto is a copy of Mr. Landry's answer. This shows that a great deal of the materials for the school building is not yet on the spot, and this material, which is logs, is not likely to be supplied this year. This meant that the contractors, who had been asked to consider it, had to be advised that there would likely be only one building left to erect.

Mr. Landry will be replaced by another in the position of Superintendent, and until such time as this change is made, very little, if anything, can be done.

G. H. Gooderham,

I have on hand your letter of July 24th bearing instructions to contact the Reverend A.L. Davies who is now school principal at that point.

I immediately sent a telegram to Mr. Davies asking him to submit all such unpaid invoices that he may have on hand and in particular the one from the J.C. Burger Lumber Company.

It is to be noted however that Mr. Davies, in all fairness, will have to be given a chance to untangle various irregularities that may have occurred prior to his arrival there. I have been informed that Reverend Davies has only arrived in Wabasca a few days ago. I feel confident however that under his administration the matter will be attended too without undue delay.

A. Landry,
Superintendent.
CALGARY, Alberta,

Col. B. F. Neary,

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, LANDS and DEVELOPMENT SERVICES BRANCH,

We are planning the erection of an agency house at Wabasca, in the Lesser Slave Lake Indian Agency. We have been able to interest Mr. Taylor of the Bond Construction Company in the erection of this building.

It was also our intention to erect a new dormitory block for the Wabasca C.E. Residential School. Originally it was intended that this school would be erected by the M.S.C.C. with the Department providing the necessary materials. However, it would seem evident that this is not now possible and that we will have to plan the erection of this building in the usual manner.

I understand that my Superintendent of Education and your Chief Architect have already discussed these two projects with Mr. Taylor. I believe that you have also arranged to have one of your engineers do a site survey at the proposed location of these two buildings. I anticipate that we will be making a request to you for the preparation of the drawings and specifications required for the erection of this classroom block when further information is received from our Regional Supervisor for Alberta.

Acting Director.
Ottawa, November 20, 1948.

Memorandum:

MR. PRATT,
Res Wabasca C.E. Residential School.

Included in our Main 1948-49 Estimates is a sum of $18,000. for the erection of this dormitory block. Some of this sum has been spent in the provision of materials required for the erection of this building. As previously discussed, it was originally intended that this dormitory block would be erected by the M.S.C.C., with the Department supplying the necessary materials. However, it is now evident that due to financial difficulties the M.S.C.C., will not be able to erect the building and that the Department will have to plan its construction in the usual manner.

Mr. W.J.F. Pratt, General Executive Assistant,

Re: Building Program - Wabasca,
Lesser Slave Lake Agency.

Superintendent Lapp and I have returned to the
Agency after five days at Wabasca, part of which time was
occupied with the Representative of the Bond Construction
Company, and Mr. Snape, Engineer of the Land and Development
Branch, locating sites for the school block and the Assistant
Agent's house, and preliminary arrangements for commencement
of construction work.

A new site on the Church of England property was
chosen. Mr. Snape favoured this because water could be easily
pumped from the lake and sewage easily disposed. The site is
less than one-half mile north of the present buildings. It is a
beautiful spot.

The principal of the school, Reverend Mr. A.L. Davies,
agreed to the location and also agreed that the pupils living
in the new building could attend their classes in the buildings
now used for that purpose.

We learned that no person has succeeded in obtaining
water from any but very shallow wells. The Hudson's Bay Company
have drilled without success. Shallow wells are uncertain and
unsatisfactory. As a result the trading company, the Church of
England Mission, the Roman Catholic Mission, and all other
residents have water in barrels from the lake on the south side.
The new site is on the north side and Mr. Snape's choice is only
a few hundred yards from the new school site and water should be
available at all times.

The Bond Construction Company will no doubt commence
work this week.

In regards to the site for the Assistant Agent's
house, we encountered difficulties in making a choice. After
surveying the whole situation carefully, lots near the new Church
of England school site was our choice because the location is
within a short walk to the schools, churches and trading post, and
centrally located near all the Indian reserves.

On the 23rd we were fortunate in meeting a man by the
name of Gladue who claims to have a title to the lot which would
be suitable. It contains 4.2 acres and on it are two log houses,
one of which was recently built and of very good construction.
Mr. Snape valued this between $150.00 and $200.00 and to this I
agreed. The owner asked $300.00 for the land and buildings. I
considered it to be a very fair price. The good house could make an office and the other an out-building. He was advised that his offer could be accepted if he could give a clear title.

I contacted the Inspector of Municipal Affairs at High Prairie today where I learned that the property is owned by a Mr. Auger who may be the same man as Gladue because these two floods can have more than one name. Before leaving the Agency this information should be supplied by Mr. Foster, Assistant Agent. There are tax arrears but it is possible that the purchase can be made at the Department of Municipal Affairs, Edmonton. This I am sure will be accepted by the Branch. I will be in Edmonton on my return to Calgary.

As the Bond Construction Company hope to excavate basements of both buildings and erect foundations before freeze up, the purchase of the sub-agency site must be made as quickly as possible. If I do not hear from you to the contrary, in care of the Charles Campbell Hospital, I will contact the Supervisor of Tax Recovery, Edmonton, and try to affect a purchase so work can be started immediately pending completion of the sale.

Sgd. G. H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.
November 23rd, 1948.

The Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch.

Re: Construction work (School Dormitory Block and Assistant Agent's Residence) Wabasca — Lesser Slave Lake — Alberta.

Referring to my memorandum of October 25th, we understand that Mr. Taylor of the Bond Construction Company is interested in the erection of both the dormitory block required at the Wabasca C.E. Residential School and also the Assistant Agent's house.

The sum of $18000.00 was provided in this year's Estimates - Education Vote - for the erection of the dormitory block. Some of this money has been spent in the purchase of the materials required for the building. You will recall that it was the original intention to have this building constructed by the M.S.C.C. However, it is now evident that due to financial difficulties the M.S.C.C. will not be able to erect the building.

Funds to the amount of $8,000.00 were provided in Indian Agencies Vote for the construction of the Assistant Agent's residence. The materials for this residence were shipped to Wabasca last winter. The materials shipped were those listed by your Architectural Service as being required to construct a residence in accordance with Plan No. NE5. I understand from Mr. Taylor that some of the materials were damaged in transit.

I also understand that the necessary plans have been prepared for the construction of the dormitory block and that Mr. Taylor
is prepared to proceed with its construction as well as with
the construction of the Assistant Agent's house. Will you,
therefore, please advise me at the earliest possible date the
estimated cost of building both these buildings having in mind
that the materials for both buildings have been purchased and
delivered. It will probably be necessary for us to arrange a
transfer of funds to both these projects as it is hardly likely
that the sum of $15,000.00 provided in the Education Vote and
$6,000.00 provided in the Indian Agencies Vote will be sufficient.
I would ask you to kindly take up with Mr. Taylor the
possibilities of completing these buildings by the 31st of March.
If this can be done, we will arrange to set up Encumbrance
Requisitions for the full amount of money required. Should
Mr. Taylor inform you that it will not be possible to complete
both buildings, you should let me know approximately how much
should be provided for the work which he will be able to complete
up to the end of March, 1949.

I believe that it would be advisable that your Branch
make all the necessary arrangements with Mr. Taylor to undertake
both projects. May I suggest, therefore, that Officers of your
Branch prepare all the necessary documents including Report to
Council and Contract Agreements and that you arrange for the
supervision of the work. As mentioned above, we will furnish you
with Financial Encumbrances for the amount of money required for
both jobs as soon as you inform us what money will be needed.
As the projects are payable from two different votes, namely,
Indian Education and Indian Agencies, you should furnish separate
estimates for each project.

From brief conversations which we have had with Mr. Taylor,
it would appear that some additional materials will have to be
purchased and, no doubt, Mr. Taylor can furnish you officers with
a list of these materials after he has visited the site and has
examined the materials which have been delivered. We will, therefore,
need to know also the estimated cost of the additional materials
which it will be necessary to allow Mr. Taylor to purchase.

Acting Director.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT it is immediately necessary and funds are provided in the 1948-49 Estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, to construct a dormitory block at the Siksika Church of England Indian Residential School, in the Lesser Slave Lake Indian Agency, Province of Alberta;

THAT these children are now living in a group of old log buildings, some of them over fifty years old, and all in a dilapidated condition;

THAT it is essential that proper dormitory facilities be provided for these Indian children;

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C., 1927, provides, in part as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest ............";

THAT building materials were purchased by the Departmental Purchasing Agent last year but that we have been unable to interest builders and contractors in Edmonton and in the vicinity of the said reserve as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL.

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT funds were provided in the 1948-49 Estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, for the construction of a Dormitory Block at the Wabasca Church of England Indian Residential School, and for a Residence for the Assistant, Indian Agency, Wabasca Indian Reserve, Lesser Slave Lake Agency in the Province of Alberta;

THAT it is essential that proper dormitory facilities be provided for the Indian children, who are now living in a group of old log buildings, some of which are over fifty years old, and all in a dilapidated and unsafe condition;

THAT it is also essential to provide living quarters for the Assistant, Indian Agency, who has been appointed to look after the affairs of these Indians and who has no place to live;

THAT owing to the isolated and inaccessible location it was necessary to have materials shipped to Wabasca during the winter of 1947-48 in order to have them on hand for construction during the summer of 1948. Materials were purchased by the Indian Affairs Branch, shipped to Slave Lake, and transported by Indian teams to Wabasca where they are stored pending the securing of a competent builder to construct the two buildings. The materials purchased for the Dormitory Block cost $10,023.07. The materials purchased for the Residence for the Assistant, Indian Agency cost $3,451.92;

THAT efforts were made to interest contractors and builders in Edmonton and the vicinity of Wabasca Indian Reserve in the construction of both the aforementioned buildings, but without success, as contractors had all the work they could do in their own districts;

THAT the Bond Construction Company, Limited, of Edmonton, Alberta, who have successfully carried out other work for the Department of Mines and Resources and who are known to be reliable and competent contractors, recently offered to construct the above-mentioned buildings by contract, on the basis of cost, plus ten per cent. (10%) of the finished cost of the work, using the materials supplied by the said Department and furnishing all other materials, labour and equipment required to satisfactorily complete the buildings;
THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C., 1927, provides, in part as follows:

"Whenever any work is to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such work except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest."

THAT it is considered that the construction of the dormitory block at Wabamun Church of England Residential School and the residence for the Assistant Indian Agent, Wabamun Indian Reserve out of pressing emergency and within the exception provided in Section 36 above rectified and further, it is considered that the work can be expeditiously and economically executed by the Bond Construction Company, who are familiar with building conditions in isolated and northern areas;

THAT including materials, furnished by the department, and after providing for the contractors' fees and unforeseen contingencies the cost of the buildings will be approximately as follows:

(a) Dormitory Building - One Hundred and thirty-two thousand dollars ($132,000.00);

(b) Residence - Eighteen thousand dollars ($18,000.00);

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted for the expenditure of the funds necessary for the construction of the above named buildings, and for the award of a contract to the Bond Construction Company Limited of Edmonton, Alberta, in the sum of proven cost, plus ten per cent. (10%) of the total cost of the completed buildings, the said total cost for the construction of the Dormitory Block and Residence for the Assistant, Indian Agency, to be met from funds provided in the 1948-49 Estimates of the Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, under Votes 216 (Indian Education) and 214 (Indian Agencies), respectively.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

I have yours of the 25th, file 767-5 (E) and have read Archdeacon Cook's letter to the Director.

It is true that the principal's residence is a half a mile to the south of the new administration building and that a hill intervenes. It is also true that there is a large number of logs and possibly other building materials which might be used in the construction of a new house. I can only recommend this expenditure if you have lots of surplus funds. I certainly could not recommend that you take funds which should be used to build day schools throughout the province, because I don't think the need is so urgent.

Over $15,000.00 has already been expended on the erection of a house for the Assistant Agency and it is not yet completed. This amount does not include most of the building material which was delivered to Wabasca last spring. This can be used as a guide as to what a new house for the principal might cost.

I have never seen the plan of the new administration building, but I understand it does not include classrooms. Therefore, the children will still attend classes in the buildings which are situated near the principal's present residence.

It is a logical assumption that he will have an assistant principal or matron in charge of the administration building, and it is my experience that unless the principal lives in the school, he must delegate responsibility to the senior assistant in his absence.

As already stated, there is considerable material on the spot, but it is not altogether suitable for house construction. Extra material will be required and it will be costly. The freight rate from railhead is still 5¢ per pound. The Archdeacon was confused between Wabasca and Whitefish.

The cost of replacement of the furnishings and fixtures in the administration building will amount to

Mr. G. S. Lepp:

Re: Purchase of Wabasca Residential School Buildings.

1. Reference is made to your letter in the above connection under date of May 6th, 1949; I have today interviewed The Reverend Mr. Davies and discussed the subject with him at considerable length. Mr. Davies and I are of the following unanimous opinions:

2. Shed - Back of Girls' Residence - valued $600.00. This shed is a very old structure. The logs in it are very badly rotted. Mr. Davies informed that he had been thinking of having this building demolished as it cannot be put to any practical use. It is currently being used to store building material and it is suitable only for keeping rain and sun off the stores it now contains.

3. With the exception of the Dining Room and kitchen all of the buildings are old log structures in extremely poor repair. Some of them could be used in connection with the operation of the new dormitory but not without renovation and alteration to suit the new requirements.

4. For instance, Mr. Davies advised me that he hopes to get another teacher and to operate two classrooms. The present classroom could continue to be used as one of them. The present Dining Room and Kitchen, with some alteration, would be a fairly good second classroom providing 40 x 24 feet of space with a fairly good amount but not sufficient light. This building is of fairly recent construction and is in good condition. It is our understanding that the two playrooms now being built into the new dormitory are to be used temporarily as classrooms.

5. The question of a Principal's Residence might be solved by converting the present Boys' dormitory into suitable quarters. This is the only building in this group which would lend itself to that purpose. Considerable and rather costly renovation and alteration would be required in this case.

6. Mr. Davies also expressed his intention to continue the maintenance of some stock. The present stable would be suitable and adequate for this purpose. It also requires some repair.

7. My statement that these buildings generally could not be put to good use without considerable expense may sound inconsistent with the fact that they are currently being made use of. In this connection I might state that, while the buildings have been used, they have not been properly maintained as it has apparently been the policy of the M.S.C.C. to get along as best they could and not to undertake any major maintenance work under wartime costs and conditions.

8. In summarizing my opinion, shared by Mr. Davies, I would say that the only buildings in question we could use would be (1) Boys' Residence (if required as Principal's Residence) (2) Dining Room and Kitchen (as extra classroom) (3) Barn (continued use as barn and (4) Present classroom which is not listed in Mr. Gooderham's letter of May 4, 1949. (Could be kept in use, if required, as one classroom).

9. To clarify the situation over the Principal's Residence, in case the reader is not aware of the circumstances, I should point out that Mr. Davies now occupies a Residence which is not owned by the M.S.C.C. but by the Athabasca Diocese. Mr. Davies points out that it is not unlikely that a Clergyman may be sent to Wabasca to relieve him of some of his present responsibilities. In that event the new Clergyman would be expected to occupy the Residence now used by Mr. Davies.

10. With the exceptions noted in para. 8 of this report, I cannot see any good use to which we could put these buildings; they could only be used as unsightly stop gaps the maintenance of which would certainly become a continuous bill of expense.

Wabasca, Alta.

P.C. 530 will have to be amended for two reasons:

correct this detail.

Estimates and financial details follow:

|                          | Agent's Residence | Dormitory Block |
|--------------------------|-------------------|-----------------|
| 1948-49 Expenditures     | 9,500.00          | 98,283.34       |
| Materials Purchased 1947-48 | 3,451.91         | 10,025.07       |
| 1949-50 Estimated maximum expenditure | 4,500.00         | 68,000.00       |
|                          | $17,451.91        | $176,308.41     |

The sum of $6,000.00 was provided by Indian Agencies to the Engineering and Construction Division to cover 1949-50 expenditures on the Assistant Indian Agent's Residence, and a surplus of at least $1,500.00 is expected.

The sum of $50,000.00 only was provided by Indian Education to the Engineering and Construction Division to cover 1949-50 expenditures on the Dormitory Block, and it will therefore be necessary to transfer an additional $18,000.00 to the Engineering and Construction Division to complete the project.

Mr. Taylor, Managing Director of the Bond Construction Company Ltd., gives a number of reasons for the increase in costs over the original $150,000.00 estimate, as follows:

1. It was originally anticipated that only one power generating unit would be required on the basis of information available at the time. When the demands of the project were studied it was established that two units were required, which accounts for an additional cost of $4,900.00.

2. The power plant was originally to have been housed in the Dormitory Block, whereas a separate powerhouse had to be built at a cost of approximately $2,500.00.

3. The Contractor was not in possession of heating specifications at the time he made the original estimate. The specifications included boiler capacity for future additional buildings and two boilers had to be installed.
4. Plumbing for the Assistant Indian Agent's Residence was not figured in the original estimate, but was later included at the request of Indian Affairs.

5. Freight and transportation cost $3,500.00 more than was anticipated.

6. The materials purchased in 1947-48 totalling $13,474.98 were figured in the $150,000.00 estimate in the belief that all the materials could be used. Changes in specifications, plus deterioration of 1947-48 materials in storage, made substitution by additional purchase necessary. There will be a surplus of 1947-48 materials which could not be used in the buildings, but which will be incorporated in future buildings.

"We are awaiting word re classrooms. Are old buildings going to be converted for that purpose? If the present classroom is not going to be used I would like permission to turn it into a henhouse. We certainly need some chickens but it is no use getting any until we have a place to put them into.

By looking at the plans of the present new Building you will see that no cupboards or shelves have been arranged for in any of the playrooms or dormitories nor in any of the storerooms. Staff bedrooms have clothes-closets, the kitchen is supplied with a goodly number of cupboards and drawers but nowhere else in the building. Now you will realize that there must be cupboards and shelves for children's clothes - they will not be able to simply throw them on to the floor. Who pays for this work? Where does the lumber come from? I asked Mr. Taylor of the Bond Const. Co. and he said they are not on the plans. This is urgent - as supervisors will be asking - where are the cupboards? There are no carpenters at Wabasca. Any work we had done was done..."
by Indians and this kind of work will not do in the New Building."

Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 10 AUGUST 1949

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report dated 7th July, 1949, from the Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

That under authority of an Order in Council P.C. 530, dated 4th February, 1949, an Agreement was entered into with the Bond Construction Company, Limited, of Edmonton, Alberta, for the construction of a dormitory block at the Wabasca Church of England Indian Residential School and residence for the Assiniboine Indian Agency, Wabasca Indian Reserve, Lesser Slave Lake Agency, in the Province of Alberta, on the basis of cost, plus a fee of ten percent (10%) of the finished cost of the work, which expenditures were estimated to total to approximately one hundred and fifty thousand dollars ($150,000.00);

That payment for the construction work embraced by the Agreement was restricted to funds provided for the purpose under Vote 218 (Indian Education) and Vote 214 (Indian Agencies) of the 1948-49 Estimates of the Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources;

That the volume of work covered by the Agreement was more than could be completed by the aforementioned contractor before the termination of the 1948-49 fiscal year, and a portion of the funds provided for the work lapsed on the 31st day of March, 1949;

That the project, now nearing completion, was subject to changes in design, namely, the addition of a plumbing system in the residence, an increase in the electric power demand necessitating added accommodation, and the discovery that certain materials stored at the site were found to be unsuitable and had to be replaced, in addition to which freight, transportation and labour costs, due to the isolated location of the project, exceeded the contractor's estimate;

That to provide funds to cover the increase in costs over the contractor's estimate, as well as to replace the funds which lapsed on March 31st last, the approximate amount of forty-six thousand dollars ($46,000) will be required;

That in the opinion of the Minister it would not be in the public interest to permit operations by the contractor to be suspended due to the lapse of funds provided under the 1948-49 Estimates.

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Minister of Mines and Resources, advise that authority be granted to arrange with the Bond Construction Company Limited, of Edmonton, Alberta, for continuous...
operation to carry the work embraced by the Agreement to completion, and to make payment for such work in accordance with the terms of the existing Agreement with the said Bond Construction Company Limited, to the estimated total of forty-six thousand dollars ($46,000) from funds provided in the Estimates of the Indian Affairs Branch, Department Of Mines and Resources, for Indian Education and Indian Agencies.

I have herewith to report that the Dormitory Building and Assistant Agent's residence was under construction by the Pond Construction Co., Ltd., at Wabasso, Alberta, were inspected on July 12th and 13th, 1949, and I have to report as follows:

Dormitory Building

(1) This building is now practically completed, consequently, it was not possible to check the construction of the rooftops, as shown on Sheets 1 and 3 of Plan #2A. The basement walls were checked where possible and I am of the opinion that if there was any departure from the plan in this part of the building, the tendency was to build too well. The basement layout conforms to Sheet 5 of Plan #2A.

(2) The first and second floors of the building have been constructed in accordance with Sheets 4 and 5 of Plan #2A. The workmanship throughout is excellent and here, as in the basement, the contractor appears to have made every effort to avoid, rather than incur, criticism. One small departure was made from the plans in the closets where a shoe shelf, not called for, was constructed above the floor level. The increase in the cost by this addition would be negligible.

(3) Those features of the building shown on Sheets 6 and 7 of Plan #2A appear generally to conform with the plans.

(4) The plumbing and heating as shown on Sheets P1, H1, H2 and H3 of Plan #2A had previously been inspected by Mr. Harpreeves and you have no doubt received his report in connection therewith. The departures from these plans, as noted by me, were as follows:

(a) In the basement laundry room a drain was constructed for a future automatic washer and the floor drain is not located as shown on the plan. This floor drain is located much nearer to the corner of the laundry adjacent to the closet.

(b) The domestic hot water tank and the pressure tank are not located in the fuel storage room as shown in the plan. These units are located in the boiler room between the stairway and the amp, the pressure tank being erected in a vertical, rather than a horizontal position.
(c) The kitchen radiator has been placed adjacent to the wall between the kitchen and the staff dining room, rather than on the ceiling, as called for on the plan.

(d) The radiator in the food storage room is 4 x 12 x 26", not 3 x 10 x 26" as called for on the plan.

(5) The wiring of the building, and the installation of electrical fixtures appears to be in accordance with Work No. 1, 2, 3 and 4 of Plan No. 4A, the only apparent difference being the installation of fire alarm bells in each of the corridors near the panels. With the exception of a few light fixtures and switch box covers all electrical fixtures were installed at the time of my inspection.

(6) The painting throughout the building was proceeding rapidly at the time of the inspection and is no doubt completed by this date.

(7) Sewage Disposal

The construction of the 6" pipe line from the dormitory building to the septic tank, the septic tank and the distribution piping through the disposal area had all been completed at the time of my inspection and the work appears to be in order.

The 4" laundry line, which bypasses the septic tank, had not yet been laid however, with the change of the work I was not in agreement. The contractor, basing on the opinion that it was not advisable to carry the laundry waste directly to the disposal bed, proposed to get rid of it by carrying the 4" laundry drain out to an excavation 10' x 10' located at the rear of the laundry drain entering the excavation hole at its bottom end at a distance of 37 feet from the foundation walls of the building. The proposal then was to fill the excavation with stone and gravel for some distance above the pipe and to carry the pipe no farther.

While there may be some merit in endeavouring to have the conglomerate from the laundry keep away below the front line before it reaches the disposal bed, I was of the opinion that this operation could not be carried enough to prevent backing up of the laundry waste drainage through the main end into the laundry. The contractor was therefore instructed to deepen the excavation to a depth of 1 to 4 feet below the entering drain and to carry this drain on the rock and gravel bed to enter the line from the septic tank as shown on the plan.

(8) Water Supply

According to Sheet A3 of the Plan 28A, it was the intention to obtain the water supply by pumping directly from the lake. Due to the shallow depth and weedy nature...
of the water for some considerable distance from the shore line it was felt that the source of supply might better be constructed at the pump house site, the depth of the well to be somewhat below lake level. Upon excavating for the well it was found that, due to the nature of the soil, there was no seepage from the lake into the well. A trench was therefore being excavated from the lake to the well, the trench to be back filled with rock and gravel through which the water could seep into the well. In addition the 12" pipe, set upside, with the exception of the intake end, was to be placed in this trench at a depth below the frost line.

There appears to be no reason why this arrangement will not work and, as the work was well along, the contractor was allowed to proceed with same.
Extract from letter from Rev. A.B. Davies, written on Aug. 17, 1949

Also in the laundry there are no electric sockets or outlet for water other than a grating on the floor. These things may seem trivial to some of these Government officials but not so to staff.

Re Classrooms - Mr. Lapp informed me yesterday that the Playrooms were to be used for that purpose. That seems to be a command - so is settled. I only hope the teachers do not mind the children playing in them during the evenings - especially in winter!

Re: Wabasca Indian Residential School,

Ottawa, September 10, 1949.

Our letter of June 24th contained detailed explanations justifying increases in the cost of constructing the Dormitory Building at Wabasca. The Contractor's original estimate for the cost of constructing the Dormitory Building and the Assistant Indian Agent's Residence was $120,000.00 including materials purchased by the Indian Affairs Branch during the 1947-48 fiscal year in the amount of $13,474.98. Mr. Taylor of the Bond Construction Company gave us a revised estimate on June 17th which indicated that the cost of constructing the Dormitory Building alone, not including the materials purchased during 1947-48 by the Indian Affairs Branch, would total $166,000.00. Since construction was nearing completion we felt that the Contractor's estimate should be an accurate one, and a request was made in our letter of June 24th for an additional $18,000.00.

Final expenditure figures were received from Mr. Taylor August 31st by telephone, and we learned that the Contractor's June estimate of $166,000.00 for the Dormitory Building (exclusive of materials purchased by Indian Affairs Branch) was too low by $24,000.00. Financial requirements for 1949-50 will therefore total $92,000.00, as follows:

With reference to the above, I wish to impress upon you the importance of protecting the new building. It is now Government property and Mr. Basler and yourself, as our representatives of that district, are responsible for its proper protection. You should assure yourself that the watchman now employed is fully competent and will carry out all instructions given to him either by you or by Mr. Basler. If you consider it necessary to employ a different man, you should so advise us, stating the rate per day you consider he should be paid.
I discussed the situation at Wabosco with the Superintendent of the M.S.C.C., this morning, and apparently they have no intention of taking over the building until all the furnishings arrive. No doubt you have received copies of Purchase Orders 48233, 48234, 48235 and 48236. We are writing to the firms concerned today and requesting them to make delivery at the earliest possible date. You should have the Station Agent at Slave Lake notify you as soon as the goods arrive, so that you may make arrangements for their delivery to the school.

We received yesterday Mr. Basler's letter of August 25th, a copy of which was forwarded to you. The items mentioned in this letter will be ordered through the Departmental Purchasing Agent, and he is being requested to obtain one 2-oven hotel range at the earliest possible date.

I enclose a copy of a letter dated August 26th received from the M.S.C.C., with reference to cupboards and shelving that we understand were not placed in the building. Please let us know by wire if any of the materials which were left at Wabosco by the Bond Construction Company, and which are in the charge of Mr. Basler, could be used for building these cupboards and lockers. Dear Canon Cook:

Re: Fuel Oil

We have just received nineteen barrels of oil from the Imperial Oil Ltd., Edmonton, there is one more barrel due. Freighter informed me that no more oil can be got unless we send out empty barrels. This is impossible as we have no storage tank and will require a large amount during the winter freighting season. What is to be done about the barrel situation? Can you get satisfaction from your end?

The twenty barrels of oil will not last more than one month if real-long - if the engine is to run 24 hours a day. It is not an automatic engine as the Government authorities thought it to be. To turn it on or off has to be done in the power engine room which is outside the main building. If Mr. Basler is to receive lights from us - then we cannot close off the engine any earlier than 1 a.m. If the engine is turned off then the fire alarm will be useless at night. I believe you said in an earlier letter that the Government would be making enquiries through their local agent about this.

What I am trying to say is - more oil will be required before winter freight rates come into operation. Have I the authority to order what is needed to hold out until winter? Then place an order for our year supply with the Imperial Oil Co. What of the barrel situation - we shall need a large number - quite expensive I think - holding the barrels at $8.00 each,

Would the Department not be interested in supplying a large storage tank then we could have an oil truck come out when the road was suitable in midwinter?

Yours sincerely,

(signed) A. L. Davies

Re: New Indian Residential Dormitory,
Wabasca, Alta.

As you are aware the new dormitory at Wabasca has now been completed and is awaiting the official turn-over to the Anglican Mission for their use.

Mr. Davies, Principal of the C. of E. School here has advised me that he does not intend to move into this building until it has been provided with shelves and cupboards and until all furnishings have been provided. He has also intimated that his Mission does not think it wise to send an engineer until the building is ready for operation in every respect. As you know furnishings and equipment for this building are on requisition and negotiations are also in progress with respect to having shelves and cupboards installed. However, due to unavoidable routine delays, these supplies are very slow in reaching here and the first load of freight for this building is only now enroute from Slave Lake to Wabasca by horse team.

Mr. Davies is currently having the old buildings put into condition for the opening of the Fall school term and for the housing of the children and by the time this report reaches you school will have commenced in the old buildings. It appears certain that the new building will not be taken into use until after the beginning of winter and I do not anticipate that it will be occupied before Christmas once school has opened in the old buildings.

It may not be fully realised in our headquarters that this situation requires very early attention as it is of the greatest importance that the building be operated, even if not occupied, before it begins to freeze. It should be pointed out that the water system throughout the building is now full of water. The boilers and tanks also contain water. The radiators in the power plant engine room are also filled with water and there is a serious danger of damage to the water pump on the lake front unless heat is provided before frosty weather sets in.

As it is certain that the building will not be fully equipped and ready for the C. of E. to assume responsibility of it before heavy frosts set in it becomes necessary for the Department to send in a man to fire it in order to protect it against possible serious damage from frost. Sufficiently heavy frosts to damage the system in the building may be expected next month.

I have examined the water and heating systems in the building to see whether I could drain all the water out of it in the event of early frosts becoming dangerous but I can not see how they can be completely drained to avoid all danger of damage through freezing if no heat is provided.

I should endeavour to make it very clear that Mr. Davies has emphasized the point that he will not assume responsibility until the building is completely ready for occupancy.

L. Basler, Asst. Indian Agent.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, LANDS and DEVELOPMENT SERVICES BRANCH,

Lighting Plant - Wabasca C.E. Residential School.

Canon Cook of the M.S.C.C. has had a discussion with the Superintendent of Education concerning the lighting plant installed in the dormitory building newly erected at the above school.

Canon Cook has requested that the present A.C. plant be replaced with a D.C. plant for the following reasons:

1. FUEL CONSUMPTION.

The following are the estimates outlining the cost of supplying fuel oil to the school based on two separate hours per diem rates of operation:

(a) Based on 16 hours a day operation; annual requirement 8,000 gal.

Winter rates of transport 2s pound
# Bbls. to be transported 178
Cost of transport = 178 X 480 X 2s = 1,708.80
Handling charge at Slave Lake 15c cwt. 128.00
Cost of fuel 20s gal. 8000 X 20s 1,600.00
Rental of drums 178 X $8.00 = 1,424.00
Return freight on drums $4.00 712.00
Loss on drums annually 712.00

$4,148.80

(b) If plant has to operate 24 hours daily add 1/3

1,382.70

$5,531.50
From the above figures it will be seen that an expenditure of at least $5,500.00 will be required annually to supply diesel fuel at this school. Yet, there is only a pupilage of 60 with the present per capita rate of $415.00 meaning a total income of $24,900.00. Therefore the cost of supplying fuel oil alone will take up approximately one third of the grant given to this school.

2. LABOUR COSTS

An A.C. plant will require operation for a period of 24 hours per day in order to maintain the fire alarm and sprinkler systems. Therefore at least three men will be required in shifts to check on the machine.

On the other hand, a D.C. plant need only be operated for a period of eight hours per day and one man only will be required to operate it.

3. Ease OF OPERATION

It is natural therefore that the strain on the machine will be much less with a D.C. plant than with an A.C. plant. Repair and maintenance costs will be lower.

4. STEEL RENTALS

With the isolated location of the school a low estimate of the amount tied up in the rental of barrels will be at least $600.00 continually. This can naturally be reduced greatly by the substitution of a D.C. system.

MEMORANDUM

Re: Dormitory Building, Webasca Indian Residential School, Alberta.

Replying to your marginal notation of the 13th instant, on Major MacKay's memorandum to you dated October 11th last in connection with safety precautions to the mechanical services at the above, you are advised that the action taken by Supervisor Gooderham is satisfactory.

You have been previously advised that so far as construction is concerned, Supervising Engineer Perrie of our Regina office, has certified that the building has been completed in accordance with the design prepared by this office and has been accepted on behalf of the Department and turned over to the local Indian Superintendent.

In addition to the above however, we have received Major MacKay's memorandum of October 6th which carried your notation of the 13th instant, and in which is set out an analysis of cost by Canon Cook of the M.S.C.C. for operation of the installed lighting plant. Canon Cook is endeavouring to convince the Indian Affairs Branch that it would be advantageous to replace the existing alternating current plant which has now been placed in operation, with a direct current unit due to the cost of fuel oil required for operation.

The type of unit installed at the school was not decided on before the demands of the present building and future extensions had been studied and approval of the Indian Affairs Branch obtained. In view of the reported urgent need for the accommodation provided by the Dormitory Building, it is considered inadvisable to consider any immediate revisions to the lighting plant.

We are satisfied that the best interests of the institution will be served by the operation of the unit now in place. Nevertheless, when Mr. Kozmar returns from his western inspection trip, we will have him contact both Canon Cook and the Director of Indian Affairs and have a full report submitted to you on the matter.

Memorandum:

CHIEF, EDUCATION DIVISION

Re: Equipment for Wabasca C.E. Indian Residential School

It appears that a request has been received to expedite the provision to this school of,

(a) Double-decker beds and mattresses.
(b) Motors for the potato peeler, ironer and washing machines (3).

The delay in providing the beds arose through the manufacturer's error in quoting. This has now been corrected and authority to purchase having been received, the order was placed with the company on the 28th of September.

The provision of the necessary A.C. motors, has, however, suffered from misunderstandings. Correspondence in this connection appears as follows:

1. General Turner's letter of March 31st, 1950.
2. Col. Neary's reply of April 3rd, 1950.
3. Mr. Lapp's letter of April 8th, in which he indicates that "arrangements were made", but they do not seem to have been finalized.
4. Mr. Gooderham's letter of April 11th, which is merely a repetition of Mr. Lapp's letter.
5. The School's requisition of August 15th, itemizing the motors required. The page on which these motors are described is not to be found in the Purchasing Agent's office.
My reading of the requisition satisfies me that no arrangements were made heretofore to have D.C. motors replaced with motors necessary to operate the machinery by the present electrical system.

A requisition for the motors is, accordingly, required by the Purchasing Agent if it is intended that this equipment is to be supplied.

Re: Water Supply-Wabasca C.E. Indian Residential School

1. Reference your letter of June 30, 1950, dealing with the above.

2. In order to make any reasonably accurate estimate of the cost of labour and materials required to ensure an uninterrupted flow of water to the dormitory on the C.E. Indian Residential School site it would be necessary to know what filter or system you have in mind. The principle of the system now in use is a filter bed near the well on the shore to which is attached an iron pipe carrying water into deep water. It was easy enough to make the filter bed deep enough but to get the pipe down to a depth of seven feet, which would be the minimum, its entire length presented the difficult problem. This was due to the fact that, for a considerable distance, the lake bottom had to be pitched under water. In order to achieve a depth of seven feet from bottom of the lake level it would have been necessary to work under water in a depth that rendered work impossible. To have the filter bed of sufficient depth and the lake end of the pipe in deep water is of little use when, for some distance in between, the pipe is elevated to a point where frost will reach it. The freezing of this pipe along its high point was anticipated by all concerned including the contractor's foreman. This difficulty remains and cannot be overcome unless a dragline is used on a breakwater built around the site of operation. None of these methods would involve prohibitive expense. For that reason I do not see how the present system can be made to work unless the Department is prepared to send in underwater equipment.

3. Having measured the depth of the lake at various distances from shore and surveyed the nature of the lake bottom, I would suggest that a satisfactory ditch could be dug immediately prior to the break-up next Spring when the frost has reached its maximum depth. This would require the use of an electric jack hammer power for which can be brought to the site without difficulty. By digging a series of holes through the ice the point where the ice touches the lake bottom could readily be found. Between this point and the well on shore it should be possible to work to a depth of eight feet and to make a satisfactory filter bed. A sump pump could be used to take care of any drainage that might accumulate while the ditch is being dug. At the point where the lake ice had reached the lake bottom and continued into the ground a natural breakwater would be formed. When the ditch and filter bed are completed the barrier formed by the ice touching the lake bottom could be opened and the water allowed to rush into the ditch and, while doing so, create its own permanent channel. The ditch would be deep enough to allow for the accumulation of dirt carried into it by the flow of water on its way to the well.

4. As a tentative date by which to be guided in making plans for this work I would say that everything should be ready to start work on March 15th.
6. I would estimate that labour requirements for this job as follows:

Four local helpers 8 days at $5.00 each - $160.00
Two operators equipped with jack hammer and sump pump 8 days at $10.00 - 160.00
Incidental local expenses such as use of horses for hauling gravel to the site and hauling away diggings, etc. - 50.00

To the above would have to be added the cost of transporting two men from Edmonton with their equipment and returning them.

All materials required would be available from left-overs from the dormitory construction job.

7. This work would make it necessary to interrupt the flow of water to the dormitory for only a few days, if at all, as the well could be filled up to the intake before work is commenced. It is probable, however, that the flow would by that time have already stopped due to natural causes.

8. Please find attached a sketch intended to illustrate the working of this plan.

9. I have given this problem very much thought and have discussed it with others and I am of the opinion that this plan is the only one that can be made to work.

10. If it is intended to simply deepen the present pipe-level the work should be undertaken during the late Fall when the water level is somewhat lower. In this case the cost would probably only be around $200.00 but it should be noted that the original crew was unable to sink the pipe to the required depth because of the interference by water and that any other crew could probably do no better.

WARASCA C.E. INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

Reference is made to your letter of the 31st of July relative to the above.

It is on record that the Contractor did not follow our plan with reference to the waste line from the laundry. Instead of connecting the laundry drain to the field disposal bed, by-passing the septic tank enroute, he was permitted to construct a rock pit to which the laundry waste line was discharged. An effluent line from this rock pit was taken and connected into the disposal field by-passing the septic tank.

We understand from a report sent in by our field engineer that this rock pit was partially filled with gravel and stone. Under these circumstances undoubtedly some of this debris has blocked the incoming line, which has resulted in the backing up of waste products into the laundry.

To alleviate this condition the rock pit should be cleaned out and no gravel, rock or earth debris put back in. The incoming drain line to this rock pit will also have to be rodded and cleaned.

The specification states that the water lines must be laid below frost line. Since two pipe lines are reported to have frozen, it is evident that this precaution was not taken.

Dear Colonel Neary:

When I saw you the other day I mentioned that I'd get in touch again regarding the new building at Wabasca. The following quotes from the report of my recent visit might form a basis for a discussion on the situation. Especially as it has been proposed that a similar building might do for the Yukon.

New Building - In very good condition inside and out and shows little evidence of having been used all winter. However there are many faults with the building most of which ought to be corrected as soon as possible:

(a) Children's dining room overcrowded with 42 pupils.

(b) Both dorms. dangerously crowded - solution might be 12 double deckers in each.

(c) No pantry in kitchen.

(d) Kitchen very hot - no air circulation possible because of window - fan ought to be installed.

(e) Laundry room inadequate - only one small floor drain for water disposal - no laundry tubs though taps fitted for same - no wall outlets for hand irons, no place to dry clothes during cold weather in whole building.

(f) No fire fighting equipment in building.

(g) No locker space in dorms or playrooms -(Lapp held money earmarked for labor on shelves and lockers but sent it back to Ottawa end of March - materials thought to be at Slave Lake though Lapp done nothing, apparently, about getting delivery at Wabasca.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6378, file 767-5, part 5)
Colonel Neary  
July 11, 1950.

(h) Septic tank giving trouble - only 2 tubs of water can be drained before sewage backs up into laundry. School engineer figures that trouble due to septic tank being in heavy clay and therefore not sufficient drain-off. Septic tank at east end of school in clay soil - west end of school of gravel and sand - so much so that the contractor increased the width of the foundation footings. Septic tank would have been better placed at west end.

(i) Pump - located in building roughly 30 feet from lake's edge in winter time intake between lake and pumphouse froze and school had to haul water. Basler's residence is supposed also to get water from same system and the line to his residence is still frozen.

Note - Bond Construction man was supposed to be at Wabasca over a week ago to look into pump situation but at time of my visit had not arrived.)

EQUIPMENT

The Beatty ironer is not set up as D.C. motors were supplied. Davies claimed A.C. were asked for and the error was made by Ottawa I.D. not he and Basler.

Large kitchen range received a few days before my visit - not installed as yet as a window - (sash and frame) has to be removed to get range in building.

Engineer wants full set of blueprints of building specifically showing electrical, sewage and water plans - Ottawa I.D. ought to be able to supply these.

Diesels require change of oil filters every hundred hours of operation - has enough on hand until February 1/51.

Classroom - Last winter classes were held in a small, ill-lighted, cold log building. Davies claims that is why Miss Thompson would not go back and why Mrs. Dauphin left - the classroom facilities were so inadequate. He proposes to use the ground floor of Unit B - partitions removed and more windows added to E and S walls. This is a good plan but really the I.D.'s responsibility.

Roothouse - No winter storage available for potatoes, turnips or carrots. Last winter much produce froze in the cellars of the unused houses even though fires were maintained. A good root cellar could be dug into the side of a hill 100 yards from school.

Playground - No level spot near the new building for a playground. Rish could be cleared and ground smoothed out if I.D. bear costs. Davies has put up some swings for the girls near the school.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Wabasca Church of England Indian Residential School.
Your File 767-5[EL]

This will serve to acknowledge your letter of April 25th in which you express dissatisfaction with the capabilities of our engineer at Wabasca.

I have to admit our present Engineer at the Wabasca School is not a certified man but with ordinary D.C. equipment as usually used in northern centres he'd be quite adequate. However as the new building is equipped with a highly automatic A.C. electrical plant his qualifications do not suffice and we are searching now for an engineer qualified to look after the equipment.

Our problem is cost. Two applications recently have been received from qualified men but one requires $225 monthly with keep and the other $60 weekly in the way of salary. You'll immediately see how impossible it is for the Administration to pay such salaries. I feel strongly that if the government places fully automatic equipment in these northern schools some adjustment ought to be made in per capita grants to allow us to pay qualified men or, failing that, the government assume the responsibility of supplying its own engineers to look after its intricate machinery.

If one may be permitted a pious hope it is that when Indian Affairs Branch has its own engineering branch it will install the simplest of equipment in its northern schools.

In the meantime we are continuing the search for a better qualified engineer for Wabasca.

Yours faithfully,

Henry G. Cook
Superintendent.

I consider that the above amounts are quite reasonable and I am prepared to recommend that these be approved by the Department.

Building materials supplied by the Department

A major difficulty has come up in attempting to determine the quantity and value of materials that were originally supplied by the Department which the Contractor may have incorporated into the building. While there is no doubt that a certain amount was used, there is evidence that large quantities were not used owing to unsuitability after having remained exposed to the weather during several months prior to the start of the project. The windows originally supplied could not be used as they did not meet with the specifications as fixed by the Architect and Engineer and I have established that unutilized quantities of materials purchased by the Department were remaining and were in the Agency's Warehouse at the conclusion of the project.

In order to bring about a settlement as early as possible, the Contractor (Mr. H. Taylor) is entitled to foreign the amount of fee on materials supplied by the Department to which he would be entitled under the terms of the contract. If this proposal meets with the approval of the Department, a serious difficulty will have been solved. For my part, I am prepared to endorse this solution otherwise, to compile a list of materials used would be an endless task which will require an air trip to Canada. From the information I have gathered in the course of my visit to the project last August, there are no indications that the Contractor has refrained from using Department materials when these could be used nor is there any reason to suspect that the Contractor has attempted to save out any of the remaining materials at the conclusion of the project.

The foregoing are the recommendations I am prepared to make concerning the various inventories, rentals and materials supplied by the Department. If you will forward these on to the Department with any other suggestions that may come to light, upon receiving approval, I shall be in a position to bring the final claim to completion.

Approved,

E. J. Blake
