Ottawa, December 20, 1937.

Dear Sir:

The Department finds it necessary to return the September quarter report of the Wabasca R.C. Residential School. In the case of pupils who were discharged during the quarter, it is noted that the Principal only requests grant for 45 days. It is also noted that, in a great number of cases, the Principal only requests grant for 73 days.

The new regulations in force this year allow 62 days holidays with grant; consequently, in the case of a pupil who is discharged, the school is entitled to receive grant for 62 days.

It is presumed that the holidays began on July 1st and that the school re-opened on September 1st, consequently, for any pupil who was in school on July 1st and returned to the school after the summer holidays grant should be requested for the actual number of days such pupil was in residence during the quarter, plus 62 days. For instance, if a pupil was allowed out on holidays on July 1st and returned on September 1st, grant should be requested for 92 days. If, however, a pupil allowed out on holidays on July 1st did not return to the school until September 10th, grant should be requested for 83 days (62 days holiday grant, plus 21 days present during the September quarter.

I enclose extra copy of this letter, in order that you may forward it to the Principal and assist him in preparing his return.

In the case of........
In the case of pupils who entered the school for the first time during the September quarter, grant should only be requested from the date of entrance to the end of the quarter. Return shows that pupils #130 and #0153 entered Wabasca R.C. Residential School for the first time on September 1st. In each instance the Principal requests grant for 30 days which is correct.

I would appreciate if you would arrange to send this return to the Principal of the Wabasca School immediately, in order that he may make the necessary corrections.

I would also point out that when quarterly returns of residential schools are received in your office, they should have immediate attention and be forwarded to the Department at once. You realize that most of the residential schools have a difficult time to finance and delay in submitting the return to the Department means that the school is not paid its quarterly grant.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

H.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

LaJoie, O.M.I., states that the Banque Canadienne Nationale has cloned its office in Edmonton, and he therefore wishes cheque in payment of per capita allowance at the above school sent to the Canadian Bank of Commerce, Jasper Ave., Edmonton, Alta.

Indian Affairs. (RG10, Volume 6379, file 768-3, part 1)
Grouard, Alta., Dec. 18th, 1939.

Mr. Phillip Phelan, Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Parliament Buildings,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

I take the liberty of asking you a new service.... Would you please notify the Department issuing cheques to direct from now on our monies to The Canadian Bank of Commerce, Jasper Avenue, Edmonton. La Banque Canadienne Nationale has closed its office of Edmonton. Our accounts have been transferred to the other bank.

About a month ago, I applied for advances on the December term. I have not heard of yet. I hope that the next mail will bring me notification that some money has been received for me. I would like to pay bills before the end of the month. If nothing has been done yet, I would appreciate you requesting the paying Department to forward some money without delay, if at all possible.

Let me profit by this opportunity to thank you for the interest you pay to our problems. Please accept my best wishes for Christmas and New Year.

Yours truly,

F. S. Lajoie, O.M.I.,
Grouard, Alta.

N.B. The number of "La Corporation Episcopale C.R. de Grouard" account is 26101 at The Canadian Bank of Commerce.
MEMORANDUM:

Please be advised that previous instructions in regard to the issue and mailing of cheques to the Roman Catholic Episcopal Corporation of Grouard, are hereby cancelled and that from this date the following procedure is to be observed,-

Make cheques payable to the Roman Catholic Episcopal Corporation of Grouard and send to the Canadian Bank of Commerce, Jasper Avenue, Edmonton, Alta.

The above change is necessary as the Banque Canadienne Nationale has closed its office in Edmonton.

Chief Treasury Officer.

LWlcc/S

Grouard, Alta., Sept. 19th, 1941.

Mr. Philip Phelan, Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Parliament Buildings,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

Would the Department consider making advances for the September term? It would be highly appreciated by me.

Let me point out that we are facing a very hard winter in the Peace River District due to bad weather. It has been raining since many weeks, especially since two weeks. The crop is rotting in the fields. No threshing done at date. It is so wet that it will be nearly impossible to pass machines in the fields. No sign of change yet. Snow in some districts. Grain and vegetables may be a complete lost.

I would appreciate receiving an affirmative answer to my inquiry re charging the Milling Mill bought to the current year credits.

Thanking you in advance for the attention,
I remain, Dear Mr. Phelan,

Yours truly,

F. S. Lajoie, O.M.I.,
Grouard, Alta.

Harold Laird,
Indian Agent,
Granard.

Kind Sir:

The present letter which I have the honor of addressing you is in behalf of the little Indian children of St. Martin's Roman Catholic Mission at Wabaska.

I was very sorry you had no time to come to our examination last summer. You would have seen for yourself, Mr. Laird.
It is very difficult it is to teach the children how to work without dishes. This is the object of my letter.

I know how devoted you are for these poor children, and that you will do all in your power to come to our aid.

I have been here a number of years and find it impossible to get on without the dishes.

Could you not get the Department to help us?

I would like to have twenty double dishes with divided sets, and six single school dishes.

Thanking you in advance for all your trouble.

Remain

Respectfully Yours,

Sister Langlois

St. Albert, Alta.

Sir:

Dear Mr. Laird:

In answer to yours dated Feb. 24th containing a copy of the letter received from the Department concerning the number of children under our care.

I can only repeat what has already been written. We have in reality 45 pupils on the roll, all of whom are Indians. You yourself personally know these families.

The four children received although not of school age, have been accepted, as declared on the application forms, because they are orphans.
I am happy to certify that the children of the Mission are enjoying good health and we believe are receiving greater care and attention than they would were they to remain at home. I could hardly refuse to accept them.

His Excellency
The Governor General in Council,

The undersigned has the honour to report that it is necessary to rebuild the Wabasca Roman Catholic Indian Residential School in Northern Alberta, as the present building is old and unfit for further use.

The Oblate Order, under whose auspices this school is conducted, are prepared to erect a new building, and have requested a grant of $15,000.00 from the Department of Indian Affairs for the purpose which, it is estimated, will represent not more than one moiety of the total cost of the undertaking.

The plans and specifications provide for a frame building suitable for the locality, with central heating and electric lighting.

In view of the remote location of Wabasca, which is some ninety miles distant from the railway line, it would appear inexpedient to call for tenders. The Church authorities have therefore undertaken to have the building constructed by day labour which is considered to be the most economical method of procedure.

As this proposal is considered to be in the interest of Indian education, the undersigned has the honour to recommend that a grant of $15,000.00 as hereinabove mentioned be authorized.

Funds for this purpose have been provided by Parliament in the vote for Indian Education for the current fiscal year.

which I would have expressed with more minute details, if I had had the opportunity of doing so.

When I first was named Principal of the Wabasca R.C. Residential School in 1923, I was very badly impressed by the sad condition of the buildings, which were built with logs some thirty years ago... the foundations are mostly worn out. Besides, the number of pupils, continually increasing; we needed more space, I then conceived the necessity of renewing the buildings as soon as possible. I communicated the idea to His Lordship Bishop Howard who in return sent me a saw-mill to prepare the lumber necessary for a new school. Our first plan was 100' x 50' with wing 30' x 40'. Then His Lordship turned to you for financial help and received a favourable reply with the sum of $15,000 for the labor, the purchase and freight of doors, windows, nails, etc. In the meantime, His Lordship
and his adviser thinking the plan too large for the $15,000 granted, greatly diminished it. By building according to this new plan, we would have been obliged to make use of the old buildings as long as they would have stood up and then to be obliged to build anew. What trouble and nuisance for the Sisters and pupils to be continually going from one house to another, especially during winter. Therefore I insisted in favor of our first plan which is now being executed and which I am sending you under separate cover.

My first idea was to install a hot air heating system but the more I think of it, the more unsatisfactory I find it, as it will hardly heat the basement and be more dangerous for fire accidents. I am very anxious to know Mr. Orr's ideas about a steam system... Would it be much more expensive?

At the present time water is being
hauled by a team and waggon two or three times a week... If the installation of a steam system with the water system were to exceed the amount already granted for our school, could I turn to you and ask if your kindness to balance the amount.

Forgive me Honourable Sir, if I have given you all these details concerning the Wabasca R.C. Residential School but they will help you to understand the situation and approve me for improving the state of things at our school.

With sentiments of esteem and best wishes, I am,

Yours sincerely,

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 19th instant, relative to fire equipment at the Wabasca R.C. Indian Residential School. In this connection it is noted that fire drill is regularly practiced and that a reliable night watchman constantly patrols the building during the night.

Regarding your request to have two chute type fire escapes installed from the dormitory windows to the ground, I have to say that the Department does not, owing to the cost involved, install this type of equipment. It is noted that there is a fire escape from each of the dormitories.

Regarding the supplying of fire extinguishers, I would request that you furnish the necessary shipping instructions. You should state the name of the railway station to which they should be sent, the distance from the school and if there would be anyone to properly look after them when they arrive at the railway station. I may say that the extinguishers we supply are the 1½ quart Pyrene and 1½ gallon Thermene extinguisher, with non-freeze chemical. You might state the number of each type of extinguisher that would be absolutely necessary for use in the school. When we have the above information, an order to supply the above extinguishers will be placed.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, August 8th, 1932.

Reverend Sir,

I have your requisition of the 16th ultimo, requesting thirty (30) additional school desks for the Wabasca R.C. Indian Residential School.

Our funds this year are so limited that I should appreciate if you would give the question of new desks some further consideration with a view to determining if you could not get along this year with a smaller number of new desks than thirty (30). The Department will await your reply before taking any action in this matter.

Your obedient servant,

A.F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Sir,

Yours of the 8th inst. re school desks for Wabasca R.C. Indian Residential School has been received.

I understand that, owing to the lack of funds, it is impossible to provide for this year the number of desks required, and I find it very considerate of you to offer us a smaller number.

I would greatly appreciate if you could grant us half of the number requested, that is, fifteen (15). Would this be too many? We could even go down to twelve, but not less, as we have a number of large pupils who need a larger size of desks.

If granted, would you kindly procure them in the following order:

| Rear Desks | No. 2 |
|------------|-------|
| 3          |       |

| Desks      | No. 2 |
|------------|-------|
| 12         |       |

Hoping to receive a favorable reply,

I am, Sir,

Yours most respectfully,

Ottawa, September 19, 1932.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, regarding the supplying of an extra quantity of school desks for use at the Wabasca R. C. Indian Residential School.

In reply I have to say that the Department is obtaining quotations for the supplying of 12 desks and 3 rear seats. I regret that, in error, a communication dated the 16th instant, requesting a quotation, was forwarded to you. This letter should have been addressed to the Western School Supply Ltd., Regina. Please cancel this letter, as we are taking the matter up with the above Company. When we obtain their quotation, you will be further advised.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

CALGARY, ALTA. August 2nd, 1933.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to report on an inspection made of the Roman Catholic Boarding School at Wabasca; I spent some time in each of the classrooms there, and found that the Indian children attending were receiving an excellent education, and that the work at this school compared very favourably with that performed at any of the schools on the outside.

There are three classrooms in the school and the grades taught are from I to VIII. I was quite surprised to find children in Grade VIII at this institution. The Senior Classroom is in charge of Sister John of Egypt, who holds a Second Class U.S. Certificate, and has taught in Indian Schools for a number of years; Sister Helen of the Crucifix, who has a U.S. standing and has taught 15 years in Alberta Indian Schools, is in charge of the Intermediate Classroom; and in the Junior Classroom is Sister Denise Helene who has a Grade X Alberta standing and who has taught for six years in Alberta Indian Schools.

Doctor Harold W. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
At the time of my visit there were 115 children in residence: 75 Indian and 30 Halfbreed children. They all looked well and it was interesting to note that after the Doctor and Nurse examined them all, there was only one boy attending the school who was not just up to the mark.

BUILDINGS:

The building is practically new and was built under the direction of the Principal in charge of the school; The lumber was all sawn on the premises as the Church authorities operate a mill there. It is three stories high and with the basement comprises four. I do not care for this kind of a building as it is very difficult to heat in the winter; You can well realize that the North winds sweeping across the lake are very cold, and the building being so high gets the full force of them. The School is heated with a hot air furnace which, of course, is not satisfactory and I believe some parts of the school are practically impossible to heat during the winter. There is a partial water system in the school: That is to say, one basin on each floor.

Another disadvantage of having such a high building is that in case of fire it is very difficult for children sleeping on the top floor to get out. Their only means of escape are either by the outside stairs from the top down to the ground, or by the inside stairway. They have fire extinguishers, &c., but
in a frame structure of this kind, it would be almost impossible to get fire under control if there was any wind.

A study building program is under way and a new barn was to be erected this summer. There are also several other new buildings in connection with the school that have recently been erected. They have a further building program in mind, as they can saw about 10,000 feet of lumber there each year.

FARMING:

The school farms 25 acres of land and they were clearing 15 acres. They also have a large garden. They own about 12 work horses and have all the implements they require, including a small threshing machine. They have about 60 head of cattle and at the time of my inspection they were milking five cows. They also make butter and the children have all the milk they can drink. They keep 100 hens.

WORK PERFORMED OTHER THAN CLASSROOM:

I also went thoroughly into the matter of other work performed by the children attending this school and found that sewing, knitting, cooking, &c., are taught to the girls, and their work compares very favourably with that of other schools. The boys are taught gardening and farm work. One thing with which I was very pleased was that they boys and girls all have gardens of their own and the school gives prizes for the best-kept garden. This is certainly a step in the right direction.
STAFF:

The Staff at the school consists of 12 Sisters of Providence, the Rev. Principal L. Beiglette, is quite an outstanding man. He has only been there a short time. He is assisted by Father E. Petour and four lay brothers, and they also give a lot of work to Indians clearing land, &c. At the time of my visit there were seven Indians employed. A night-watchman is also employed.

I must say that this is a splendid institution and is carrying on good work. It is situated right on the banks of the lake, and when they have completed their buildings and fixed up their grounds according to their plans, it will be a beautiful place.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,

Sir:

I have been directed to acknowledge receipt of your No. 406-11A, R.C., of the 2nd instant, reporting on the inspection made by you or the Roman Catholic Indian Residential School at Wabasca.

The Department is pleased to note that conditions generally at this school are satisfactory, that the pupils are receiving a good educational training, and that their health is good.

The Department is drawing the attention of His Lordship Bishop Guy, under whose auspices this school is conducted, to the fire hazard, due to the construction of the building. He is being requested to take the matter up with the Principal and staff and see that every precaution is taken. I may add that the services of a night watchman are engaged at this school.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, August 18, 1933.

Right Reverend Sir:

Mr. Inspector Christianson, in a report on his inspection of the Regina R.C. Indian Residential School, states that he found conditions generally to be quite satisfactory and that the children are receiving an excellent education and training under the Reverend Sisters. He found the children in excellent health.

However, the Inspector has drawn attention to certain fire hazards resulting from the type of building - two stories with basement. He states the building is difficult to heat in winter and the disadvantage of having such a high building is that, in case of fire, it is extremely difficult for children sleeping on the top floor to get out - their only means of escape being either by the outside stairs from the top down to the ground or by the inside stairway. The Inspector states that the building is a frame structure, and, while they have a good supply of fire extinguishers, it would be almost impossible to get fire under control if there was any wind.

I am drawing your attention to the Inspector's report only as it refers to danger from fire. I am sure that every precaution is taken by the principal and staff - there being a night watchman at the school. However, I should be pleased to have your views as to whether every provision has been made to overcome fire hazard and, in case of fire, if the necessary facilities are available that the children can leave the building.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Right Reverend Jos. Guy, O.M.I.,
Bishop of Grouard,
Grouard, Alta.

Edmonton, March 3rd, 1935.

Mr Harold W. McGill, M.D.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Doctor McGill:

During a recent visit to St Martin's Indian Residential School, Wabasca, I found out that the lighting system was being handicapped through the deficiency of the Batteries. The latter have been quite looked after but of course have served their time and purpose. They will not stand the year's run and in fact we are wondering if they will last the whole Winter.

Consequently I have taken upon myself to ask for tenders and I am enclosing the lowest from the J.H.Ashdown Hardware Company of Edmonton, for your kind consideration and approval with request of course of payment by the Department.

I may add that freighting to Wabasca School is possible only during Winter and therefore only one more month is left for said freighting. In consideration of that fact I would take the liberty of asking for prompt action and would ask for the favor of a telegram to be sent either to me or to the J.H.Ashdown Company in Edmonton. If you wire me please note that I will in Grouard until the 9th inst when I leave for Ottawa where I expect to be on the 18th.

With anticipated thanks for above and pleasure of meeting you soon, I remain

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Bishop of Grouard.

He states the batteries at present in use have outlived their usefulness. His Lordship forwards a quotation from the J. H. Ashdown Hardware Company, Limited, Edmonton, for the supplying of Globelite batteries, Type GD13 - 56 cells, at $526.00 less allowance for old glass jars, $34.60, making the total net cost, f.o.b. I beg to recommend that the order be placed with the above firm, as per their quotation.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report, dated 6th November, 1935, from the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, representing:

That building operations enumerated hereunder were carried out during the past summer at each of the St Bernard's, St Bruno's, Sturgeon Lake and Wabasso Roman Catholic Indian Residential Schools, located in the Lesser Slave Lake Indian Agency, northern Alberta;

That as these schools are in an isolated locality, it has been found that the most economical method of arranging for construction is to place the work in charge of the Oblate Order, under whose auspices they are conducted;

That all work was approved by the Department and carried out on a day labour basis, under the direct supervision of His Lordship Right Reverend Joseph Guy, S.M.I., Bishop of Grouard, at a cost of $24,800.

That the cost of the work at each school, including material and labour, was as follows:

St Bernard's:
Erection of a new building, to provide classrooms, sewing room, dormitory and laundry................$16,000.

St. Bruno's:
Repairing foundation, main building - $5,500.
Erecting kitchen - $1,400.
Erecting barn - $1,500

Sturgeon Lake:
Miscellaneous repairs, school buildings $500.

Wabasso:
Erecting machine shed and chicken house $2,100.

That funds to cover the cost of the above mentioned work are provided in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year, 1935-36.

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, advise that authority be granted for the expenditure of the said sum of $24,800, in payment of the cost of the above mentioned work.

Dr. Harold W. McGill, Dep. Super. General,

Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. McGill,

I take the liberty of forwarding to the Department a bill of Beatty Bros. Ltd., for Laundry machinery destined to R.C. Residential School at Wabasca. You would oblige me greatly if you could pay this bill directly to the Company.

Allow me to call your attention on the fact that the Company is requesting payment for the 26th of February. By the notes left by His Lordship Mgr Guy, O.M.I., I see that there should be a credit for Laundry Machinery at Wabasca. In order to avoid debts, I have bought a rather small laundry equipment. I have done so only after having requested the advice of the Sisters who have testified that such equipment would be sufficient.

If you foresee that the bill will not be paid for the mentioned date, you please notify me. I would not like to deceive the Beatty Bros. Co.

Believe me, Dear Mr. McGill,

Yours very truly,

F. S. Lajoie, O.M.I.,
Grouard, Alta.
Grouard, Alta., Feb. 15th, 1938.

Dr. Harold W. McGill, Dep. Super. General,

Dear Mr. McGill,

On the 31st of January last, I was addressing you a few words presenting a bill of Beatty Bros for Laundry machinery bought from these people for R.C. Residential School at Wabasca. I was pointing out that the Company was requesting payment by the end of this month.

Please find enclosed a letter I have just received from the same firm on this matter. The letter talks by itself. Not to deceive these people, I take the liberty of communicating it to the Department with the hope that it will be possible to answer the request. Should that be impossible, I would appreciate you getting in touch with Beatty Bros. stating that the bill will be considered at the earliest convenience possible.

Grouard, Alta., Jan. 25th, 1938.

Mr. Phi. Phelan,
Indian Affairs Department,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

I take the liberty of directing to you the documents in connection with the painting of the R.C. Indian Residential School of Wabasca, Desmarais, Alta. This work was authorized last year by what I understand from His Excellency Mgr Joseph Guy, O.M.I.

Allow me, Mr. Phelan, to make you a confession... I am awfully short of money. I have not received a cent on all the work done last summer. To pay bills and wages on this work, I have been compelled to delay other payments. Besides, I have not touched yet the allocations for the Wabasca School, I mean the balance due on September term and all the term of December. If you could do something to alleviate the burden. I am so worried with that money question.....

Your are aware that the Department has agreed through the Hon Minister to pay so much a year on the money we borrowed to rebuild the Boys' School. Having in his mind that we could borrow money at 3½%, the Hon. Minister has stated in his communication $2,500.00. This amount has proved not to be sufficient to pay interest and a valuable instalment as it was impossible to get money as less than 4%. Lately, Mgr J. Guy wrote to the Hon. Minister requesting him to raise the amount to $3,000.00 a year. On the reception of the bill for the first six months interest and instalments, I have forwarded this bill to Dr McGill inquiring of the intention of the Department to pay directly to the lenders or through the Corporation. If you happen to be consulted on the matter, I would appreciate advising to pay directly. It makes business easier.
I would appreciate receiving some large envelopes for reports, communications with the Department.

Thanking you in advance for the attention you will give to the questions referred to in this letter,

I remain,

Dear Mr. Maclean,

Yours very truly,

F. S. LaJoie, C.M.T.,
Administrator,
Grouard, Alta.

Wabasca R.C. Residential School.
Appropriation: $2,000.00

Work to be done includes chimneys. Estimated cost .............$ 1,200.00

The material was bought early in January last to be hauled on winter roads. We pay an average of two cents a pound in winter when it costs five or six cents for summer hauling, when it is possible to do. Besides, when I was notified to purchase through the Department's Agent, all the stuff had reached Wabasca since weeks.

Work to be done includes Diesel engine. Estimated cost ..........$ 850.00

The old engine for the electric plant got out of order last winter. As replacement could not be deferred, the Principal took on him to buy a new one. This was before I was notified to pass through the Department for any purchase. Besides, when I heard, the deal had been done.

With this engine, we will save a lot on gas and oil. Nevertheless, had it not been absolutely needed, it would not have been bought. It was out of question to leave the Mission without light and power for a month or so.
